LlXw3rcM.title: Characterization of boron-doped TiO2 nanotube arrays prepared by electrochemical method and its visible light activity
LlXw3rcM.abstract: The boron-doped TiO 2 nanotube arrays were fabricated by potentiostatic anodization of titanium in an aqueous electrolyte containing fluoride ion and sodium fluoroborate (NaBF 4 ). The highly ordered nanotube arrays with an inner pore diameter of approximately 80 nm and a length of 1.4 μm are obtained. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data indicate that the boron atoms are successfully incorporated into the TiO 2 matrix, forming Ti–B–O bond in the sample with small amount of boron (1.5 at.%), and the chemical environment surrounding boron is more similar to that in B 2 O 3 in the samples with larger amounts of boron (3.1 and 3.8 at.%). The B-doped TiO 2 nanotube arrays with a mixture of anatase phase and very little rutile phase upon thermal annealing at 500 °C for 2 h were identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD). Red shifts and enhanced absorption intensities in both UV and visible light regions are observed in the spectra of UV–vis absorption of B-doped samples. The B-doped nanotube arrays show improved photochemical capability under both simulated sunlight and UV irradiation. By comparison, the sample with 3.1 at.% of boron exhibits the best photoelectrochemical properties, and its photocurrent densities under simulated sunlight and UV irradiation are approximately 1.17 and 1.27 times of those of TiO 2 nanotube arrays, respectively. The visible photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) activities of the prepared electrodes were evaluated using atrazine as a test substance under simulated sunlight irradiation. The kinetic constant of PEC degradation of atrazine using B-doped electrode with 3.1 at.% of boron is 53% higher than that using non-doped one. A synergetic effect of the photocatalytic (PC) and electrochemical (EC) processes is observed. Keywords Boron doping TiO 2 nanotube arrays Potentiostatic anodization Visible photoelectrochemical activity 1 Introduction One-dimensional nanostructures with nanotubular symmetries are proved to be very efficient as physical and chemical nanodevices due to their valuable high surface area structure, and offer great potential applications in the sensing, fuel cells and water photolysis [1] . Beginning with the discovery of carbon nanotubes [2] , the variety of interesting properties of the material has stimulated a series of approaches to synthesize nanotublar structures other than carbon. TiO 2 , one of the most promising photocatalyst, has attracted special attention due to its high photocatalytic (PC) activity, chemical stability, nontoxicity and relatively low price. Therefore, particular attempts are carried out to fabricate the vertically oriented TiO 2 nanotube arrays by electrochemical (EC) anodization in order to further improve its properties to meet the practical application requirements [3–5] . Compared with any other form of titania, the highly ordered nanotube arrays possess large internal surface area, and their unique architectural characterization and crystalline nature make them attractive electron percolation pathways for vectorial charge transfer between interfaces [6,7] , thus, convincing TiO 2 nanotube arrays be worthy of scientific consideration. Furthermore, the oxide tubes grow directly on the Ti sheet by the simple anodization method, which strengthens the adhesion of TiO 2 nanotube arrays to the substrate; in addition, the parameters, such as the pore size, the length and the wall thickness, can be precisely controlled by tailoring the EC conditions [8–10] . In recent years, TiO 2 nanotube arrays have been applied in water photoelectrolysis, photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) degradation of organic pollutants and used as photoelectrode in solar cell [11–13] . Titania dioxide has long been regarded as an attractive photocatalyst, however, it is photochemically active only under UV light irradiation; especially TiO 2 nanotube, its band gap is even wider than that of TiO 2 nanofilm [12] . Therefore, considerable efforts have focused on band-gap engineering of titania. One approach is to sensitize TiO 2 with suitable dyes [7,13] , while the dyes occur self-degradation under irradiation [14] , thus, limiting its practical applications. The other approach is to modify TiO 2 by elemental doping. It has been proved that anion-doped TiO 2 , such as nitrogen-, carbon-, or sulfur-doped TiO 2 , all exhibit visible photoresponse [15–17] . Currently, there are two major explanations for anion-doped effect that lead the absorption edge of TiO 2 to shift to the visible region. Asahi et al. [15] proposed that N-doping caused the narrowing of TiO 2 band gap, producing TiO 2− x N x with visible photoactivity. Carbon- and sulfur-doped TiO 2 displayed similar behavior under visible light irradiation. Some studies, however, proposed that the isolated band, which was introduced by anion dopant, formed above the O 2p valence band, causing two-step electronic transitions, that is, from valence band to localized states and then from localized states to the conduction band of TiO 2 [18,19] . While Serpone suggested that the red shift of the absorption edge was due to the formation of the color centers, not to a narrowing of the original band gap of TiO 2 through mixing of dopant and oxygen states [20] . Accordingly, it is a viable way to improve the visible response of TiO 2 by anionic doping, although the doping mechanism needs to be further studied. Based on the consideration of smaller radius of boron than that of nitrogen, it is logical for boron incorporating into TiO 2 matrix easily. The preparation of B-doped TiO 2 by sol–gel method has been reported [21,22] , however, this method was only used for preparing B-doped TiO 2 in powder form and could not be suitable for fabrication of ordered TiO 2 nanotube arrays produced by anodization method. We have previously reported on boron incorporation by chemical vapor deposition on anodically formed TiO 2 nanotube arrays [23] and found it conceivable to prolong the absorption edge of TiO 2 nanotube arrays to visible region by boron doping, but it was a two-step fabrication approach and the preparation process was relatively complex. In this paper, we develop a one-step way to prepare B-doped TiO 2 nanotube arrays by EC oxidation of Ti sheet in the electrolyte containing boron. The aim of this study is to investigate the effect of different boron contents on the structure characteristics and the photoelectrochemical capabilities of B-doped TiO 2 nanotube arrays. The PC oxidation efficiency can be enhanced by applying low bias potential across the photoanode and the PEC oxidation is becoming a welcome technology in wastewater treatment. Thus, the PEC activity of B-doped samples was also evaluated by PEC degradation of atrazine (2-chloro-4-ethylamine-6-isopropylamino- s -triazine), a widely used herbicide, under simulated sunlight irradiation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of B-doped TiO 2 nanotube arrays Titanium sheet (99% pure) with a thickness of 0.5 mm was anodized to produce TiO 2 nanotube arrays. NaBF 4 of different concentrations from 0.625 to 2.5 mM was added to the electrolytic solutions. The choice of this kind of compound was based on the considerations of its chemical property, that is, it could not affect anodization process; and of its chemical composition so as to restrain the electrolytic ions and control other possible elements, which might be incorporated into the anodic titania films. More details of anodic oxidation had been described previously [23] . To induce crystallinity, the initially amorphous as-anodized films were annealed at 500 °C for 2 h with heating and cooling rates of 2 °C min −1 . 2.2 Characterization Morphological characterization of the samples was carried out using environmental scanning electron microscope (ESEM; Quanta 200 FEG). Direct cross-sectional image was taken from cracked layers after bending the samples. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis using a diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (Shimadzu LabX XRD-6000) was used for determining the crystalline structure of the samples. The elemental composition of the samples was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; AMICUS). The UV–vis spectra were recorded on a Jasco UV-550 spectrophotometer with an integrating sphere; BaSO 4 was used as a reference sample. 2.3 Photoelectrochemical measurements The photocurrent density was measured using a CHI EC analyzer (CH Instruments 650B, Shanghai Chenhua Instrument Co. Ltd., China) in a standard three-electrode configuration with the prepared sample as the working electrode, a platinum foil as the counter electrode and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the reference electrode in 1 M KOH electrolyte. A 350-W high-pressure mercury lamp (Beijing Huiyixin Lighting Co., China), or a high-pressure xenon short arc lamp (CHF-XM35-500W, Beijing Changtuo Co., China) that was introduced as a spectra physics solar simulator, was applied as the radiation source. 2.4 Photoelectrocatalytic experiment The PEC oxidation of atrazine was carried out in a single photoelectrochemical compartment. The B-doped TiO 2 nanotube array photoanode, a platinum foil cathode and a SCE as the reference electrode were all connected to the CHI 650B EC analyzer. Bias potentials applied on photoanode were 0.6 V (vs. SCE) in the experiments. The spectra physics solar simulator with the illumination intensity of 80 mW cm −2 at the position of photoanode was placed in parallel with the photoreactor. All the experiments went on with continuous magnetic stirring, using 0.01 M sodium sulfate as the electrolyte. The initial concentration of atrazine aqueous solution was 10 mg L −1 . The determination of atrazine concentration was performed by HPLC (Waters 2695, Separations module) with a Sunfire™ C 18 (5 μm) reverse-phase column at 30 °C equipped with photodiode array detector (Waters 2996). The mobile phase was 1.0 mL min −1 of methanol and water (v:v = 0.55:0.45) and the spectrum was chosen at the wavelength of 220 nm. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology of B-doped TiO 2 nanotube arrays Fig. 1 shows ESEM images of B-doped TiO 2 anodized in the electrolyte containing 1.25 mM NaBF 4 . Clearly, the structure consists of self-organized and ordered nanotubes with an inner diameter of approximately 80 nm, a wall thickness of approximately 15 nm and a length of approximately 1.4 μm. It is apparent that B-doped sample still keeps nanotubular structure with no significant morphology change, which is also found for the samples anodized in the electrolyte with lower (0.625 mM) and higher (2.5 mM) concentrations of NaBF 4 (figures not shown). 3.2 XPS analysis Fig. 2 shows the B 1s XPS spectra of B-doped samples with the NaBF 4 concentration in the anodization electrolyte ranging from 0.625 to 2.5 mM. The intensity of B 1s peak increases with the increase of NaBF 4 concentration and the amounts of boron are estimated as 1.5, 3.1 and 3.8 at.%, respectively, indicating that the amount of boron dopant is a linear function of boron addition when the NaBF 4 concentration is below 1.25 mM. Furthermore, the B 1s peaks gradually shift from 192.6 to 193.4 eV with the increase of boron amount, suggesting more of B–O bonds on the surface of B-doped TiO 2 sample. Referring to the standard binding energies of B 1s in B 2 O 3 (193.1 eV, B–O bond) and in TiB 2 (187.5 eV, Ti–B bond), it is speculated that boron atom might probably be incorporated into the TiO 2 matrix, forming Ti–B–O bond in the sample with small amount of boron (1.5 at.%), while the chemical environment surrounding boron in the samples with larger amounts of boron (3.1 and 3.8 at.%) is more similar to that in B 2 O 3 . The Ti 2P 3/2 peaks of B-doped samples are observed at about 459.8 eV (figures not shown), shifting to larger energy in comparison with that of Ti 2P 3/2 in TiO 2 (459.0 eV), which implies that oxygen atoms in the lattice of TiO 2 might be partially substituted by boron atoms and a stable state is formed [21] . However, further investigation is needed to get the detailed information on the anodization involving BF 4 − to form B-doped TiO 2 . 3.3 Effect of boron on the crystallinity of TiO 2 nanotube arrays In order to examine the effect of boron dopant on the structure of TiO 2 nanotube arrays, XRD patterns for non- and B-doped samples are presented in Fig. 3 . It can be seen that the crystallized structures for doped samples mainly consist of anatase phase (corresponding to 2 θ = 25.4°) and little amount of rutile phase (corresponding to 2 θ = 27.5°) due to boron doping. The increase in the crystallite sizes calculated from the Scherrer equation of the doped samples might be attributed to the fractional phase transfer from anatase to rutile. It is known that the solid-phase transformation is a process of nucleation and growth [24] . At low temperature (500 °C in this work), the net transformation rate is limited by the rate of rutile nucleation [25] . By contrast with pure TiO 2 , the partial substitution of O atoms for B atoms causes a decrease of the TiO 2 content in B-doped TiO 2 samples and the amount of anatase particles also decreases to some extent; therefore, it is speculated that at the same annealing temperature, the small anatase particles of the doped samples tend to become bigger, and thus, the rutile nucleation might occur at the subset of anatase interfaces. For TiO 2 nanotubes, the rutile crystallites originate in the oxide layer underneath the nanotubes [11] and the phase transition from anatase to rutile during annealing is inhibited by nano-dimensional nanotube walls [26] . Therefore, it is suggested that the appearance of rutile phase is attributed to boron doping, while the unique nanostructure hampers its growth to some extent. On the other hand, the rutile peak of the sample with medium boron amount is sharper and more intensive, indicating that this sample could exhibit higher PC activity than the others under visible light. 3.4 UV–vis absorption spectra The effects of boron doping on the light absorption characteristics of TiO 2 nanotube arrays are shown in Fig. 4 . The B-doped samples all exhibit red shifts in the band gap transition and the absorption edge in the spectrum of sample with 3.1 at.% of boron has the biggest red shift of approximately 30 nm, which might be attributed to the rutile phase existence, since rutile has a narrower band gap than anatase. The band gap energies estimated with Kubelka–Munk function [27] of pure TiO 2 is about 3.33 eV, of B-doped TiO 2 (3.1 at.% of boron) is about 3.10 eV, and of the other two doped samples (1.5 and 3.8 at.% of boron) are both about 3.16 eV. In addition, the B-doped samples also exhibit stronger absorption in the UV–vis range. The results of the absorption feature suggest that B-doped TiO 2 nanotube arrays could be activated by visible light and might exhibit enhanced photoresponse under UV light as well. 3.5 Photoelectrochemical measurement The photocurrent densities as a function of applied potential of TiO 2 nanotube array and B-doped TiO 2 nanotube array electrodes, in a 1 M KOH electrolyte, under simulated sunlight irradiation (80 mW cm −2 ), are shown in Fig. 5 . The dark current is so low that can be negligible and the photocurrents are calculated from the measured currents subtracting the respective dark one. Clearly, the photocurrent densities of B-doped samples are higher than that of non-doped one, and the slope to the titania's photocurrent–potential characteristic also increases, implying that under the same irradiation with the same bias potential, more photoexcited electrons on the B-doped TiO 2 electrode flow to the cathode, leaving more photoexcited holes involved in the oxidation reaction. The improved photoelectrochemical properties of B-doped TiO 2 nanotube array electrodes could be attributed to boron doping, which gives the direct evidence that the B-doped TiO 2 nanotube array electrodes prepared in this work can improve the visible photoresponse of TiO 2 nanotube arrays, and thus, may find its application in photoelectrochemical degradation of organics under sunlight irradiation. By comparison, the photocurrent density of the sample with 3.1 at.% of boron is the highest among the samples, which is approximately 1.17 times of that of TiO 2 nanotube arrays, and the photocurrent density of the sample with 3.8 at.% amount of boron is a little higher than that of the third-doped sample (1.5 at.% of boron). Therefore, 3.1 at.% is an optimal doping amount and the sample with such boron amount exhibits the best photoelectrochemical capability than the others under simulated sunlight irradiation. The photoelectrochemical behaviors of B-doped TiO 2 nanotube array samples under UV light irradiation (0.75 mW cm −2 ) are also investigated with results displayed in Fig. 6 . In accordance with the discoveries under simulated sunlight irradiation, increased photocurrent densities are observed due to boron doping, which causes the titania electrode more sensitive to UV light (see Fig. 4 ), and the photocurrent density of the sample with 3.1 at.% of boron is approximately 1.27 times of that of TiO 2 nanotube arrays. In addition, the photocurrent density increases with the increase of boron dopant till the boron amount reaches 3.1 at.%, and further increasing the boron-doping amount in the B-doped sample leads to a decrease of its photocurrent density. Therefore, 3.1 at.% is an optimal doping amount and the sample with such boron amount exhibits the best photoelectrochemical capability under UV light irradiation. 3.6 Photoelectrocatalytic degradation of atrazine Visible photoelectrochemical activity of B-doped TiO 2 nanotube array electrode is evaluated by PEC degradation of atrazine in an aqueous solution under simulated sunlight irradiation. As Fig. 7 shows, more atrazines are removed on B-doped electrode with 3.1 at.% of boron, and the atrazine removal increases by approximately 32% than on non-doped one. It is also found that atrazine removals on the other two B-doped electrodes (1.5 and 3.8 at.%) are higher than that on TiO 2 nanotube array electrode, but both are inferior to the one with 3.1 at.% of boron. The atrazine degradation follows pseudo-first kinetic equation, and the kinetic constants of atrazine photoelectrocatalysis are 1.08, 0.907, and 0.863 h −1 on the electrodes with 3.1, 3.8, and 1.5 at.% of boron, which are 53%, 29% and 23% higher than that on TiO 2 electrode (0.704 h −1 ), respectively (see Table 1 ). Obviously, the atrazine removal rates in PEC process on B-doped electrodes are all faster than that on TiO 2 electrode, proving the contribution of boron dopant in improving visible activity of TiO 2 . The sample with 3.1 at.% of boron exhibits the best activity, which is in good agreement with the results of photocurrent density test in Fig. 5 . With respect to photoelectrocatalysis, the function of the bias potential acts in promoting photogenerated charges as to increase the lifetime of electron–hole pairs [28] . Fig. 8 shows the atrazine degradation on the electrode with 3.1 at.% of boron in four different processes, that is, EC, direct photolysis (DP), PC and PEC. It is anticipatory that almost no atrazine is removed in EC process, affirming that the bias potential of 0.6 V is too low to induce atrazine degradation. It is reasonable that atrazine removal efficiency in PC process is higher than in DP process, proving that B-doped TiO 2 nanotube array electrode can be excited under sunlight irradiation and partial photogenerated holes involve oxidation reaction before combination. Furthermore, more atrazine is removed on the B-doped electrode when a low bias potential (0.6 V vs. SCE) being applied to produce a PEC oxidation reaction. After irradiation, the degradation efficiencies of atrazine in EC, DP, PC and PEC processes are about 2.36%, 34.7%, 53.2% and 66.8%, respectively. The reaction kinetics is undergone by linear fit and corresponding kinetic constants in four processes on B-doped sample are shown in Table 2 . Clearly, there is a synergetic effect between the PC and EC processes. 4 Conclusions This work reports an EC method for producing B-doped TiO 2 nanotube arrays. Boron atoms are successfully incorporated into the TiO 2 matrix during the process of anodization which occurrs in the electrolyte containing fluoride ion and NaBF 4 . The B-doped electrodes display a clear increase in their photocurrent densities, confirming that the boron doping would improve the photoelectrochemical capabilities of TiO 2 nanotube arrays. Furthermore, the B-doped sample with 3.1 at.% of boron exhibits the best photoelectrochemical and PEC performance under simulated sunlight irradiation. Accordingly, it is suggested the feasibility of EC method for fabricating B-doped TiO 2 nanotube arrays and such material would be promising in visible photoelectrocatalytic region. In summary, efforts have been made to investigate the unique properties of TiO 2 nanotube arrays, but the researches on their modification with anion elements for further utilization of solar energy are still limited. We believe it is necessary to investigate more solar energy related applications of B-doped TiO 2 nanotube array material. These will be the subjects of ongoing studies. uG8GqMuK.title: Cobalt implanted TiO2 nanocatalyst for heterogeneous activation of peroxymonosulfate
uG8GqMuK.abstract: In the past decades, catalyst stability and metal ions leaching have always been one of the most important issues in the heterogeneous peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation system. In this work, cobalt implanted TiO2 was proposed as an effective catalyst for improving the catalyst stability and inhibiting cobalt leaching. A simple hydrolysis method was employed for the preparation of nanocatalysts with Co(NO3)2·6H 2O and Ti(OC3H7)4 as precursors. Characterization by X-ray diffractometry, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and temperature programmed reduction indicated that the doped cobalt uniformly distributed in the faces of TiO2 crystallite as Co2+ and interacted with TiO2 through a strong Co-O-Ti bond. Compared to the Co3O4 immobilized TiO2 catalysts, the cobalt ion implanted TiO2 nanocatalysts reduced half of the cobalt dosage but exhibited paralleled catalytic activity and, moreover, the cobalt leaching declined about 60%. The reduction of cobalt dosage, uniform distribution of Co2+ in the TiO2 crystal lattice and the strong interaction of Co2+ with TiO2 support were believed to improve the performance in heterogeneous activation of peroxymonosulfate (PMS) and decrease the cobalt leaching. © 2013 The Royal Society of Chemistry.

ss0bdG2Y.title: Electrocatalytic debromination of BDE-47 at palladized graphene electrode
ss0bdG2Y.abstract: Graphene electrodes (Ti/Gr) were prepared by depositing Gr sheets on Ti substrate, followed by an annealing process for enhancing the adhesion strength. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopies and X-ray diffraction patterns displayed that the electrochemical behavior of Ti/Gr electrodes can be improved due to the generation of TiO2 layer at Ti-Gr interface during the annealing process. The palladized Gr electrodes (Ti/Gr/Pd) were prepared by electrochemical depositing Pd nanoparticles on Gr sheets. The debromination ability of Ti/Gr/Pd electrodes was investigated using BDE-47 as a target pollutant with various bias potentials. The results indicated that the BDE-47 degradation rates on Ti/Gr/Pd electrodes increased with the negative bias potentials from 0 V to -0.5 V (vs. SCE). Almost all of the BDE-47 was removed in the debromination reaction on the Ti/Gr/Pd electrode at -0.5 V for 3 h, and the main product was diphenyl ethers, meaning it is promising to debrominate completely using the Ti/Gr/Pd electrode. Although the debromination rate was slightly slower at -0.3 V than that under -0.5 V, the current efficiency at -0.3 V was higher, because the electrical current acted mostly on BDE-47 rather than on water. ? 2014 Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.

SM8cNt7v.title: Electrochemically enhanced adsorption of phenol on activated carbon fibers in basic aqueous solution.
SM8cNt7v.abstract: Electrosorption isotherms and thermodynamics of phenol on activated carbon fibers (ACFs) in basic solution, as well as the factors (bias potential, initial concentration, and electrolyte) affecting adsorption/electrosorption kinetics, were investigated. The kinetics, which followed the Lagergren adsorption rate law, exhibited a variety of responses depending on bias potential, initial concentration, and electrolyte. The electrosorption isotherms were in agreement with the classical models of Langmuir and Freundlich, but the former gave more satisfactory correlation coefficients. With electrosorption at a bias potential of 700 mV from the basic solution, a nearly 10-fold enhancement of maximum adsorption capacity was achievable. The electrosorption free energy (DeltaG(ads)), enthalpy (DeltaH(ads)), and entropy (DeltaS(ads)) of phenol on the ACFs were calculated from adsorption isotherms at different temperatures. The results indicated that electrosorption of phenol in basic solution was spontaneous and exothermic. Furthermore, it was assessed that electrosorption occurred by dipole-dipole interaction with DeltaH(ads) of -20.14 kJ mol(-1) besides suppositional electrostatic interaction.

ZpoLQdxs.title: Competitive adsorption and desorption of copper and lead in some soil of North China
ZpoLQdxs.abstract: The competitive adsorption and desorption of Pb(II) and Cu(II) ions in the soil of three sites in North China were investigated using single and binary metal solutions with 0.01 mol·L -1 CaCl 2 as background electrolyte. The desorption isotherms of Pb(II) and Cu(II) were similar to the adsorption isotherms, which can be fitted well by Freundlich equation (R 2>0.96). The soil in the three sites had greater sorption capacities for Pb(II) than Cu (II), which was affected strongly by the soil characteristics. In the binary metal solution containing 1:1 molar ratio of Pb(II) and Cu(II), the total amount of Pb(II) and Cu(II) adsorption was affected by the simultaneous presence of the two metal ions, indicating the existence of adsorption competition between the two metal ions. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was used to investigate the interaction between soil and metal ions, and the results revealed that the carboxyl and hydroxyl groups in the soil were the main binding sites of metal ions. © 2012 Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.

aSr27jEk.title: Improvement of antifouling and antimicrobial ability on silver-carbon nanotubes based membranes under electrochemical assistance.
aSr27jEk.abstract: Excellent fouling resistance to various foulants is crucial to maintain the separation performance of membranes in providing potable water. Antimicrobial modification is effective for antibiofouling, but fails to mitigate organic fouling. Improving surface charges can improve the resistance to charged foulants, while the lack of antimicrobial ability results in bacterial aggregation. Herein, a silver nanoparticles modified carbon nanotubes (Ag-CNT)/ceramic membrane was prepared with enhanced antifouling and antimicrobial properties under electrochemical assistance. The presence of silver nanoparticles endows the composite membrane with antimicrobial ability by which inhibits biofilm formation. Its steady-state flux is 1.9 times higher than that for unmodified membrane in filtering bacteria suspension. Although the formation of organic fouling did weaken the biofouling resistance, the negatively charged bacteria and organic matter can be sufficiently repelled away from the cathodic membrane under electrochemical assistance. The flux loss under a low-voltage of 2.0 V reduced to <10% from >35% for membrane alone when bacteria and organic matter co-exist in feed water. More importantly, silver dissolution was significantly inhibited via an in-situ electro-reduction process, by which the Ag+ concentration in effluent (<1.0 μg/L) was about two orders of magnitude lower than that without voltage. The integration of antimicrobial modification and electrochemistry offers a new prospect in developing membranes with high fouling resistance for water treatment.

e8oheLee.title: Integrating plasmonic nanoparticles with TiO 2 photonic crystal for enhancement of visible-light-driven photocatalysis
e8oheLee.abstract: Aimed at enhancing photocatalysis through intensifying light harvesting, a new photocatalyst was fabricated by infiltrating Au nanoparticles into TiO 2 photonic crystals (TiO 2 PC/Au NPs). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) images showed that the Au NPs with average diameter around 15 nm were dispersed uniformly into the porous TiO 2 material. The results of the transmittance spectra demonstrated that the light absorption by Au NPs was amplified after they were infiltrated into TiO 2 240, which was fabricated from 240 nm polystyrene spheres. In the photocatalytic experiments of 2,4-dichlorophenol degradation under visible light (> 420 nm) irradiation, the kinetic constant using TiO 2 240/Au NPs was 2.3 fold larger than that using TiO 2 nanocrystalline/Au NPs (TiO 2 NC/Au NPs). The excellent photocatalysis benefited from the cooperatively enhanced light harvesting owing to the localized surface plasmon resonance of Au NPs, which extended the light response spectra and the photonic effect of the TiO 2 240 which intensified the plasmonic absorption by Au NPs. The hydroxyl radicals originated from the electroreduction of dissolved oxygen with photogenerated electrons via chain reactions were the main reactive oxygen species responsible for the pollutant degradation. © 2012 American Chemical Society.

zCxyXQdB.title: Enhanced adsorption of PFOA and PFOS on multiwalled carbon nanotubes under electrochemical assistance.
zCxyXQdB.abstract: Removal of perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) and perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS) from aqueous solution has attracted wide attention in light of their environmental persistence, bioaccumulation, and potential toxicity. Although various destructive technologies were developed, removal of PFOX (X = A and S) under mild conditions are still desirable. In this work, multiwalled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) were applied to remove PFOX in electrochemically assistant adsorption. Electrosorption kinetics and isotherms were investigated relative to open circuit (OC) adsorption and adsorption on powder MWNTs. Compared with powder MWNTs adsorption, the initial adsorption rate (υ(0)) of 100 μg/L PFOX at 0.6 V increased 60-fold (PFOA) and 41-fold (PFOS) according to pseudosecond-order kinetics model and the maximum electrosorption capacity (q(m)) of PFOX (50 μg/L to 10 mg/L) increased 150-fold (PFOA) and 94-fold (PFOS) simulated with Langmuir model. These significant improvements were assumed to benefit from enhanced electrostatic attraction under electrochemical assistance. Furthermore, the used MWNTs were found to be regenerative and reusable. This work provides not only a new approach to effective removal of perfluorochemicals from aqueous solution but also a low energy-consumption and environmentally-friendly strategy for application of carbon nanotubes in water treatment.

MJ41P3IC.title: High photocatalytic capability of self-assembled nanoporous WO3 with preferential orientation of (002) planes.
MJ41P3IC.abstract: Self-assembled nanoporous tungsten oxide (WO3) with preferential orientation (002) planes was successfully synthesized on the tungsten sheet by anodization in a 0.2 wt % NaF and 0.3% (V/V) HF mixture solution in a 1:1 ratio. The pores, of a highly ordered self-assembled structure, had an average size of approximately 70 nm. X-ray diffraction identified a monoclinic WO3 structure and fine preferential orientation of (002) planes. A maximum photoconversion efficiency of 17.2% was obtained for the self-assembled nanoporous WO3 under high-pressure mercury lamp illumination. The photocatalytic (PC) degradation of pentachlorophenol (PCP) in aqueous solution using the self-assembled nanoporous WO3 photocatalyst, performed under both high-pressure mercury lamp and Xe lamp illumination, showed more excellent PC capability than WO3 film and TiO2 nanotube arrays.

oR7NjIxd.title: Removal of p-xylene from an air stream in a hybrid biofilter.
oR7NjIxd.abstract: Biofiltration of an air stream containing p-xylene has been studied in a laboratory hybrid biofilter packed with a mixture of mature pig compost, forest soil and the packing material which was made of polyethylene (PE) and used in the moving bed biological reactor (MBBR) in wastewater treatment. Three flow rates, 9.17, 19.87 and 40.66 m(3)m(-2)h(-1), were investigated for p-xylene inlet concentration ranging from 0.1 to 3.3 g m(-3). A high elimination capacity of 80 g m(-3)h(-1) corresponding to removal efficiency of 96% was obtained at a flow rate of 9.17 m(3)m(-2)h(-1) (empty bed residence time of 132 s). At a flow rate of 40.66 m(3)m(-2)h(-1) (empty bed residence time of 30s), the maximum elimination capacity for p-xylene was 40 g m(-3)h(-1) and removal efficiencies were in the range of 47-100%. The production of carbon dioxide (P(CO(2))) is proportional to elimination capacity (EC) and the linear relation was formulated as P(CO(2))=1.65EC+15.58. Stable pH values ranging from 6.3 to 7.6 and low pressure drop values less than 0.2 cm H(2)O (19.6 Pa) of packing media in compost-based biofilter of hybrid biofilter were observed, which avoided acidification and compaction of packing media and sustained the activity of microorganism populations.

JRGxf1ca.title: Enhanced azo dye wastewater treatment in a two-stage anaerobic system with Fe0 dosing.
JRGxf1ca.abstract: Azo dye wastewater treatment was enhanced in an acidogenic reactor (A1) by Fe(0) dosing. Both COD (50%) and color (60%) removal in A1 were stable when the dye concentrations were increased from 200 to 800 mg/L. However, the performances of a Fe(0)-free control reactor (A2) showed low COD (34%) and color (32%) removals. The reason was attributed that Fe(0) dosing enhanced the activity of fermentative bacteria, which played an important role in acidogenesis and decolorization. The methanogenic reactor fed with the effluent of A1 exhibited higher removal efficiency and treatment stability. These results suggested that Fe(0) powder dosing was helpful to improve acidogenesis and decolorization to create a favorable feeding condition for the subsequent methanogenic treatment.

w73EprM0.title: Sorption of perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS) on oil and oil-derived black carbon: influence of solution pH and [Ca2+].
w73EprM0.abstract: Sorption of perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS) to oil and oil-derived black carbon (BC) from solutions varying in pH and [Ca(2+)] was investigated. Oil is a strong sorbent for PFOS, together with the independence of oil-water distribution coefficient (K(oil)) on solution parameters (pH values and [Ca(2+)]), suggesting that hydrophobic interactions of the hydrophobic moieties of PFOS with oil played a dominant role. BC sorption for PFOS is not stronger or more nonlinear than other natural organic carbon from solution in the case of 0.5mM [Ca(2+)] and pH 5.05, indicating that specific adsorption sites on BC were probably not fit for PFOS. However, both sorption capacity and nonlinearity of PFOS increased obviously with decreasing solution pH and increasing [Ca(2+)], resulting in the potential importance of BC at environmentally low PFOS level, from solution at high [Ca(2+)] or low pH. The role of BC in PFOS sorption was significantly influenced by environmental conditions and solute aqueous concentrations.

ANGKkpqP.title: Optimization of anaerobic acidogenesis by adding Fe0 powder to enhance anaerobic wastewater treatment
ANGKkpqP.abstract: Acidogenesis is responsible to convert complex organics into volatile fatty acids (VFA), whose metabolic rate and production type have important effects on the whole anaerobic digestion. A novel strategy for enhancing anaerobic wastewater treatment via dosing Fe powder (40g) in an acidogenic reactor (2L) is described. The results showed that the hydrolysis/fermentation was accelerated by Fe dosing. As a result, the acidogenic performances in COD removal (45-56%) and VFA production (1170-1340mg/L) were less affected by shortened hydraulic retention time (HRT) from 6 to 2h. However, COD removal declined to 25% and VFA production decreased to 661mg/L in a reference reactor without Fe0 dosing (A2). Besides, Fe0 dosing optimized fermentation type, namely, the production of propionate was decreased, which was favorable for subsequent acetogenesis and methanogenesis. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis indicated that Fe0 dosing increased the abundance of acidogens, especially acetogens. The methanogenic reactor fed with the effluent of A1 had higher COD removal and treatment stability with almost no propionate detected. These results suggested that the enhancement of acidification by Fe0 powder dosing was helpful to accelerate and improve anaerobic acidogenesis to create a favorable feeding condition for the subsequent treatment. © 2012 Elsevier B.V..

LilYPtPP.title: Sensitive amperometric determination of chemical oxygen demand using Ti/Sb–SnO2/PbO2 composite electrode
LilYPtPP.abstract: A novel Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 composite electrode was fabricated for COD determination. The new electrode configuration improved the sensitivity of the amperometric method apparently. Effects of common experimental parameters, such as applied potential, pH and concentration of the electrolyte on its analytical performance were investigated. A linear range of 0.5–200 mg L −1 COD and a detection limit (a signal-to-noise ratio of 3) of 0.3 mg L −1 were achieved under optimized conditions. The experiments for detecting COD in model samples and real samples were carried out to evaluate the electrode's performance. The obtained results were in good agreement with those determined by the standard dichromate method, with a relative error less than 12%. Keywords Chemical oxygen demand Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode Amperometric detection 1 Introduction Chemical oxygen demand (COD) is an important parameter for the evaluation of water quality [1] . The most common COD determination method is dichromate titration, which has been established as a standard method in many countries. This method involves time-consuming and tedious analytical procedure, consumes some toxic (Cr 6+ , Hg 2+ ) and expensive (Ag 2 SO 4 ) chemicals as well, which have drawn many attentions to shorten the analysis time [2,3] and reduce the consumption for toxic chemicals. However, the existing method and its modified methods are required to be conducted in a laboratory, where reflux digestion equipments (for example, the equipment used in regular chemical digestion, microwave-assisted digestion or ultrasound-assisted digestion) are available. This limitation makes these methods not suitable for onsite measurement, which is helpful for monitoring the water quality on time. To achieve COD onsite measurement, several new methods for COD determination have been developed including photocatalytic oxidation method [4–7] , photoelectrochemical method [8–14] , and electrochemical method [15–21] . Previous reports indicated the reproducibility and low dynamic range of COD value determined by photocatalytic oxidation method were influenced by the oxygen content in the tested water [13] , since these methods used oxygen molecules as electron acceptors to scavenge electrons leading to the decrease of dissolved oxygen in water and interference on COD determination. By introducing a potential bias to scavenge electrons, the photoelectrochemical method effectively overcame the shortcomings of photocatalytic oxidation method. Nevertheless, the utilizing of UV light and electronic field complexes the configuration of measurement device and increases the device cost. Due to its relative simple device and directness in the acquisition of analytical signal, electrochemical measurement was proposed as a suitable and competitive method for COD onsite measurement. In electrochemical detection process, organic compounds in testing water are oxidized by the hydroxyl radicals ( OH) produced on working electrode and generated electrical signals, which is proportional to COD values. Based on this detection mechanism, the key point for COD electrochemical detection is to fabricate or find an ideal and adoptable working electrode, which determines the quantity of OH generated under available condition. Several kinds of working electrodes have been developed for this purpose. Rossler-Fromme and Scholz [15] and Orozco et al. [16] fabricated composite electrodes consisting of graphite, AgO, and CuO, and reported their properties for COD determination. However, the available potential for those electrodes is not high enough to oxidize all the organic compounds. Yu et al. reported boron-doped diamond (BDD) electrode with satisfied potential and its good performance for COD determination due to its wide electrochemical potential window [17,18] . Nevertheless, its fabrication process is complicated and requiring special instrument leading to high cost of BDD. Compared with these electrodes, PbO 2 electrode and modified PbO 2 electrode have significant price advantages with good performance for COD detection. The lowest detection limit was 2.5 mg L −1 with the response current 0.8 μA per mg L −1 COD for F-PbO 2 electrode or nano-PbO 2 on Pt wires electrode [19–21] , which still has an improvement space for COD determination in order to better comply the determination requirement for surface waters with low COD values. In this work, a novel Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 composite electrode was fabricated and its electrochemical sensing behaviors for COD determination were firstly investigated. The net steady-state electronic current originated from electrocatalytic oxidation of organic compounds was used as the analytical signal for COD determination. The analytical performance of the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 composite electrode with a high potential of oxygen evolution was compared with the Ti/F-PbO 2 electrode, which showed that the new Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 composite electrode exhibited good performance for COD determination and its sensitivity was significantly improved. The effects of important parameters on the analytical signal were investigated systematically. Based on the optimized parameters, real sample analyses were also performed by the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 composite electrode. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Glucose, sucrose, p -hydroxybenzoic acid, hydroquinone, p -nitrophenol, sodium fluoride, and tetracycline (analytical grade) were obtained from Tianjin Bodi Chemicals Co. Ltd. (Tianjing, China). Tin tetrachloride (SnCl 4 ·5H 2 O) and lead nitrate (Pb(NO 3 ) 2 ) were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, USA). Sb 2 O 3 nano-particles with 30–50 nm diameter were obtained from Institute of Fangyuan Nano-material (Anhui University of Technology, China). Real samples were collected from reservoir, domestic sewage treatment plants and factories near the city of Dalian, stored in dark at 4 °C and analyzed within 48 h. All solutions were prepared by Milli-Q water (18 MΩ cm). 2.2 Equipment All electrochemical measurements were carried out with a PARSTAT 2273 electrochemical system (Princeton applied research, USA). Morphologies of Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 composite electrodes were characterized by environmental scanning electron microscope (SEM, Quanta 200 FEG, the Netherlands). X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected by a diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (Shimadzu LabX XRD-6000, Japan). 2.3 Preparation of Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 and Ti/F-PbO 2 electrodes Ti plates (0.5 mm × 15 mm × 30 mm) were used as electrode substrates, which was firstly polished with 500-grit and 1500-grit sandpapers sequentially, then immersed into 40% NaOH solution at 80 °C for 2 h, and further etched with 20% oxalic acid at 96 °C for 6 h, afterwards they were washed with deionized water and acetone in turn for a few minutes. The fabrication of Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 composite electrode followed two steps. The first step was to achieve a Sb–SnO 2 layer modified Ti electrode (Ti/Sb–SnO 2 electrode) by electrodepositing Sb–SnO 2 layer onto the Ti plate followed by thermal decomposition, as described in Ref. [22] . In brief, electrodeposition was carried out in a two-electrode system, which was employed with Ti plate as the working electrode, and a platinum plate as the counter electrode with a constant DC current of 60 mA between the two electrodes for 30 min. The electrolyte used in the electrodeposition consisted of 3.5 g SnCl 4 ·5H 2 O, 0.15 g Sb 2 O 3 nano-particles, and 0.4 mL HCl (37 wt.%) dissolved in 20 mL alcohol. Afterwards, the Ti plate calcined in an oven at 400 °C for 2 h was dipped into a precursor solution containing 6 g SnCl 4 ·5H 2 O, 0.16 g Sb 2 O 3 nano-particles, and 0.5 mL HCl (37 wt.%) dissolved in 10 mL n -butanol. The dipping–calcining procedure was repeated up to 5 times at room temperature, and then the electrode was annealed in an oven at 550 °C for 2 h. The whole first step described above was repeated five times to obtain an Sb–SnO 2 layer modified Ti electrode (Ti/Sb–SnO 2 electrode). The second step was implemented in a common three-electrode system by electrodeposition using the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 electrode as the working electrode, a platinum plate as the counter electrode and a saturated Ag/AgCl electrode as the reference electrode to achieve the final Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 composite electrode. During the second electrodeposition, 2.6–3.0 V potential ( vs. Ag/AgCl) was applied for 0.5–2.0 min under gently stirring. The electrolyte consisted of 125 mM HClO 4 , 20 mM Pb(NO 3 ) 2 and 20 mM NaF. The temperature during the second step was maintained at 80 °C. A Ti/F-PbO 2 electrode was prepared according to the methods presented by Cong and Wu [23] and used as a control electrode to compare its performance with that of the new Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 composite electrode for COD determination. The process for Ti/F-PbO 2 electrode fabrication was illustrated briefly as following. After the pretreatment mentioned above, the Ti plate was immersed into the precursor solution containing Pb(Ac) 2 , NH 4 -Ac, and (NH 4 ) 2 S 2 O 8 for 1 min and calcined at 500 °C for 1 h, with the whole process repeated up to 5 times. Afterwards, it was used as the working electrode to be electrodeposited forming a Ti/F-PbO 2 electrode in a common three-electrode system with a platinum plate as the counter electrode and a saturated Ag/AgCl electrode as the reference electrode. The electrolyte was a mixture of 500 mM Pb(NO 3 ) 2 , 200 mM HNO 3 and 25 mM NaF. During the electrodeposition, a potential of 2.6 V vs. a saturated Ag/AgCl electrode was applied for 2 min, and hydrogen peroxide was added into the electrolyte to eliminate the formation of NO 2 − . 2.4 COD measurement procedure COD measurements were performed in a conventional three-electrode system with a Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode as working electrode (effect area was 200 mm 2 ), a platinum plate and a saturated Ag/AgCl as the counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively. The measuring and signal quantification procedures are as follows: a steady blank current ( i blank ) of the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode in 18 mL 25 mM Na 2 SO 4 supporting electrolyte solution was recorded when the potential vs. the reference electrode was applied. 2 mL model sample solution or real sample solution was mixed with the Na 2 SO 4 supporting electrolyte solution to obtain a steady total current ( i total ). The difference between i blank and i total was achieved and defined as i net . After each COD measurement, a potential of 3 V vs. the reference electrode was applied for 30 s to clean the working electrode completely. During each measurement and cleaning, the solution was stirred gently by a magnetic stirrer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Measuring principle and signal quantification According to the electrocatalytic reaction mechanism, the organic compounds are oxidized on the surface of the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode, where hydroxyl radicals ( OH) are generated by the discharge reaction. With the powerful oxidizing properties of OH, organic pollutants are oxidized indiscriminately, gradually forming dehydrogenated or hydroxylated derivatives, and finally being decomposed to carbon dioxide and water [24,25] , as described in formula (1) . (1) M( OH) + R → M + CO 2 + H 2 O + H + + e − where M( OH) represents hydroxyl radicals produced on the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode; R is organic pollutants. During this process, the electrochemical charge originated from this reaction would simultaneously generate a proportional signal current, which could be used to quantify the concentration of organics in a sample (formula (2) ): (2) i n e t = n k A F Z c c R where n is the number of electrons attending the oxidization reaction, k is reaction constant of (1) , Z c is the stoichiometry factor for the complete combustion of organic pollutants, A , F , and c R are area of the electrode, Faraday constant, and the molar concentration of organic pollutants, respectively. According to the definition of COD, c R can be converted to COD/8000 n. Herein, i net can be represented as: (3) i n e t = k A F [ COD ] 8000 From formula (3) , it is obvious that i net is proportional to COD of organic pollutants. Besides, in our determination method, i net was obtained by subtracting i blank from i total . i blank and i total were the current produced on the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode before and after the addition of samples into the electrolyte solution. 3.2 Characterization of the electrodes The surface morphology of the electrodes before and after PbO 2 electrodeposition was characterized by SEM and XRD, shown in Figs. 1 and 2 . The morphology of Ti/Sb–SnO 2 electrode exhibits a typical mud-crack structure ( Fig. 1 a), which is a typical characteristic of other oxide electrodes fabricated by a thermal decomposition method [26,27] , because of the thermal expansion coefficient differences between Ti substrate and the Sb–SnO 2 layer. It is shown in Fig. 1 b that after the electrodeposition of PbO 2 , the Sb–SnO 2 layer including the cracks on its surface is completely covered by PbO 2 particles diameter of 200–500 nm ( Fig. 1 b), which can greatly increase the surface area of the composite electrode and the density of adsorption sites. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of Ti/Sb–SnO 2 electrode and Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode. In comparison of these two XRD patterns, the crystallographic characteristics of PbO 2 at 2 θ = 25.3, 35.9 and 48.8 are clearly identified, which suggests that the existence of PbO 2 on the surface of Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode. The other intense peaks at 2 θ = 26.4, 33.7 and 51.6 correspond to SnO 2 , which are slightly different with those of pure SnO 2 due to the coexistence of Sb [28] . In addition, the same peaks in the two XRD diagrams ( Fig. 2 a and b) at 2 θ = 38.2, 39.9 and 70.4 belong to Ti substrate. All the evidence illustrate the formation of Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode. 3.3 Response of Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode to glucose Fig. 3 shows a set of typical i net -time profiles of Ti/Sb–SnO 2 , Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 and Ti/F-PbO 2 electrodes with the successive addition of glucose (10 mg L −1 COD). After the addition of glucose, the oxidative currents immediately increase and reach 95% or 98% of the steady state within 10 s for Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 and Ti/F-PbO 2 , respectively. While, although the current response of Ti/Sb–SnO 2 electrode also performs well to the successive addition of glucose, as proved by the electrochemical degradation of phenols [21] , the sensitivity to the organics is not high enough to be used as COD determination sensor. Compared to the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 electrode, it is apparent that the larger i net of Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 and Ti/F-PbO 2 are attributed to the high catalytic performance and large surface area of the nano-PbO 2 on Ti sheet. Moreover, it is worth noting that the i blank of the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode was much lower than that of Ti/F-PbO 2 electrodes, which is benefit to distinguishing minor i net from i total , suggesting it is more sensitive on COD determination. Hence, this suggested that the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 composite electrode is more favorable for COD determination compared to Ti/F-PbO 2 electrode. 3.4 Optimization of the measuring conditions 3.4.1 Applied potential To obtain an appropriate potential for COD measurement, a series of amperometric response to the addition of 10 mg L −1 COD glucose were investigated at different potentials. The results ( Fig. 4 ) show that i net increases gradually with the potential increasing from 1.3 V to 1.55 V. While further increasing of potential to 1.60 V leads to the obvious decrease of i net . On the other hand, i blank almost keeps a constant value with the potential ranging from 1.30 V to 1.40 V. However, once the potential exceeds 1.50 V, i blank increases rapidly caused by the evolution of oxygen on the composite electrode. In addition, although i net achieves the largest value at 1.55 V, the current stability and reproducibility of the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 composite electrode drop down (data not shown). Consequently, 1.40 V is chosen as the applied potential in further investigation. 3.4.2 pH and concentration of electrolyte solution Because the solution pH can affect both the production of OH on the electrode surface and the chemical forms of organic compounds in the solution, these pH dependent factors may affect the analytical signal. The effects of pH, ranging from 2 to 11, on both the i net and i blank were investigated and shown in Fig. 5 . It is apparent that both the i net and i blank increase with the increasing of pH, but the increasing rates are different. At the beginning, i net increases rapidly within the pH range of 2–3. Then it increases slightly as the pH value increases from 3 to 9. This phenomenon is consistent with that basic solution is favorable for OH generation. On the other hand, the increasing of pH leads to the lower over potential for oxygen evolution as well. Herein, when pH value of the solution is over 10, oxygen evolution gradually becomes the main reaction compared to the oxidization reaction of organic pollutants, leading to a rapid increase of i blank . Thus, the suitable pH range for the COD determination is 3–9. The electric conductivity of solution is another influencing factor in most electrochemical reaction. As the electric conductivity of solution is associated with the concentration of supporting electrolyte, we investigated the effects of different concentrations of Na 2 SO 4 solution (10–60 mM) as supporting electrolyte on i net and i blank . The results show little change in i net within this Na 2 SO 4 concentration range, while i blank increases slightly due to the increase of the conductivity. Accordingly, the medium low concentration of the electrolyte, 25 mM, was selected in the following experiments. 3.5 COD electrochemical determination based on the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode Fig. 6 shows the relationships between i net , measured at 1.4 V in 25 mM Na 2 SO 4 , and the theoretical COD values of the six kinds of model sample solution, which is calculated based on the concentration of the organic compound postulated to be oxidized completely. The six kinds of samples are glucose, sucrose, nitrophenol, hydroquinone, p -hydroxybenzoic acid and tetracycline solution, which are common organic compounds in water representing carbohydrate, phenols, carboxylic acid, and antibiotics, respectively. i net increased linearly with the increase of theoretical COD values ( Fig. 6 ) with almost the same slope for the six investigated samples, demonstrating that the relationship between i net and COD values is independent on the type of organic species. The linear range for COD determination is 0.5–200 mg L −1 and the detection limit is estimated to be 0.3 mg L −1 (a signal-to-noise ratio of 3), which is lower than those of F-PbO 2 electrode or nano-PbO 2 on Pt wires electrode [19–21] . Moreover, the reproducibility of COD determination based on the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode is satisfied with relative standard deviations of interior-day and inter-day less than 5.0% and 10%, respectively. 3.6 Analysis of real samples To investigate the feasibility of the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode for COD determination of real samples, several real water samples from reservoir, municipal sewage plants, and factories were analyzed. The pH values of the samples were in the range of 5–9, which is within the proper pH range for COD determination. The COD values determined by the conventional method (dichromate method) were used as control values. All the samples with high COD values were diluted to a proper concentration before analyzed by the proposed electrochemical method or dichromate titration method. The comparison of COD values performed by the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode with the COD values determined by the conventional method is listed in Table 1 , which shows that the values obtained by the two methods are consistent, with relative errors less than 12%, illustrating the good performance of Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode on COD determination. 3.7 Interference of chloride ion Considering chloride ion is an ordinary reductive ion in water, and it is one of the major factors influencing COD measurement by dichromate titration method [29] , the effects of chloride ion concentration on the COD determination by Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode were investigated (shown in Fig. 7 ). The concentration range of Cl − selected in this experiment was from 10 to 200 mg L −1 , covering the normal Cl − concentration level in domestic water (30–100 mg L −1 ). It is worth noting that the concentration of Cl − plays a positive role on the i net producing on the Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode, leading to measurement errors ( Fig. 7 ). Furthermore, the corresponding ratio of i net to [Cl − ] ( i net /[Cl − ]) rises with the increasing of Cl − concentration. For example, i net /[Cl − ] is 0.024 μA as the concentration of Cl − is 10 mg L −1 , and it rises to 0.078 μA with the concentration of Cl − up to 100 mg L −1 . Therefore, dilution before COD determination is necessary for the samples with large amounts of Cl − and high COD value, in order to prevent the measurement errors caused by Cl − interference. As for a sample with large amounts of Cl − but low COD value, precipitation of Cl − by the addition of Ag + before COD determination is a feasible and optional method. 4 Conclusion In this study, a novel Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 composite electrode with good analytical performance was fabricated for COD amperometric determination. Under the optimized conditions, an excellent correlation between i net and COD value ( i net = 2.059COD + 0.3762, R 2 = 0.9910) and a low detection limit (0.3 mg L −1 ) were achieved, which were comparable to or better than those of previously reported F-PbO 2 electrode or nano-PbO 2 electrode. Ti/Sb–SnO 2 /PbO 2 electrode would be extremely attractive in the field of COD electrochemical determination for surface water or other clean waters with low COD values. Technol. 100 2009 979 982 Chuanjun Ma is a PhD candidate in environmental engineering at School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, China. His current research interest is functional material for the determination of chemical oxygen demand. Feng Tan received his PhD from Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2005. He is a research assistant at School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, China. His research interest is novel technologies for environmental analysis. Huimin Zhao received her PhD in environmental engineering from Dalian University of Technology, China, in 2002. She is an associate professor at School of Environmental Science and Engineering. Her research interests are functional material and their applications in environmental monitoring. Shuo Chen received her PhD in environmental engineering from Dalian University of Technology, China, in 2004. She is currently an associate professor at School of Environmental Science and Engineering. Her research interests are application nanomaterials in environmental field. Xie Quan received his BSc in Chemistry from Northeastern Normal University in 1982 and MSc in Environmental Science in 1986 from Nanjing University, China. He completed his PhD in 2000 at University of Graz, Austria. He received “Grantee of the National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars” in 2005 and Professor of “Chang Jiang Scholars Program’ in 2005. His interests are focus on water pollution control, environmental monitoring, and environmental material application.

7CneZVrG.title: Investigation of Pentachlorophenol Vertical Transportation in Soil Column During its Phototransformation on the Soil Surface
7CneZVrG.abstract:
Pentachlorophenol (PCP) vertical transportation in soil column during its phototransformation on the soil surface was investigated
 using a new designed photoreactor. Three kinds of soils were used to study the effect of soil water and soil properties. In
 air-dried sandy loam, no obvious PCP transportation occurred in the soil profile when PCP was phototransformed on the soil
 surface. And the average removal of PCP in the whole soil column was close to zero after 48 h irradiation. In the moist sandy
 loam, PCP in the deeper soil could transport to the soil surface with water evaporation and then be transformed during UV
 irradiation, thus the average PCP removal in the whole soil column was improved. When the initial water contents are 9.3 and
 19.2%, the average PCP removal in the sandy loam after 48 h irradiation accounted to 20.9 and 39.9%, respectively. The improving
 of PCP removal induced by soil water was limited in the clay and silt soils where PCP transportation was impeded because of
 their higher adsorption capacity. In the silt soil where the initial water content was 19.7%, not only PCP transportation
 in the deeper soil but also PCP phototransformation on the surface was inhibited seriously because of the high organic matter
 content of 18%.

VRxUWIGX.title: Atrazine photodegradation in aqueous solution induced by interaction of humic acids and iron: photoformation of iron(II) and hydrogen peroxide.
VRxUWIGX.abstract: The photochemical formation of Fe(II) and hydrogen peroxide (H 2O 2) coupled with humic acids (HA) was studied to understand the significance of iron cycling in the photodegradation of atrazine under simulated sunlight. The presence of HA significantly enhanced the formation of Fe(II) and H 2O 2, and their subsequent product, hydroxyl radical ( (*)OH), was the main oxidant responsible for the atrazine photodegradation. During 60 h of irradiation, the fraction of iron presented as Fe(II) (Fe(II)/Fe(t)) decreased from 20-32% in the presence of the Fe(III)-HA complex to 10-22% after adding atrazine. The rate of atrazine photodegradation in solutions containing Fe(III) increased with increasing HA concentration, suggesting that the complexation of Fe(III) with HA accelerated the Fe(III)/Fe(II) cycling. Using fluorescence spectrometry, the quenching constant and the percentage of fluorophores participating in the complexation of HA with Fe(III) were estimated by the modified Stern-Volmer equation. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) offered the direct evidence that Fe(III)-carboxylate complex could be formed by ligand exchange of HA with Fe(III). Based on all the information, a possible reaction mechanism was proposed.
VRxUWIGX.venue: Journal of agricultural and food chemistry

qmNMYVyA.title: Separation of phthalocyanine-like substances from humic acids using a molecular imprinting method and their photochemical activity under simulated sunlight irradiation.
qmNMYVyA.abstract: To elucidate the existence of phthalocyanine-like (Pc-like) substances in humic acids (HA) and their roles in photochemical transformation of organic pollutants, Pc-imprinted polymers (MIP) were synthesized successfully and employed to separate Pc-like substances from HA. The fraction bound by MIP (F(mip-b)) presented better photochemical activity for degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) in aqueous solution irradiated by simulated sunlight. The pseudo-first-order rate constant of 2,4-D photodegradation with the presence of F(mip-b) was 2.5 times as high as that in solution containing effluent fraction (F(eff)). These results show the key role of some HA with special structures in photochemistry and are helpful for better understanding phototransformation of environmental contaminants in natural aquatic systems.
qmNMYVyA.venue: Journal of agricultural and food chemistry

JXtllBKD.title: Photoelectrocatalytic degradation of pentachlorophenol in aqueous solution using a TiO2 nanotube film electrode.
JXtllBKD.abstract: Titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanotube film electrodes are fabricated by the anodic oxidation method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) showed that these tubes were well aligned and organized into high-density uniform arrays. XRD analysis showed the TiO2 nanotubes to be in the anatase crystal form. The TiO2 nanotube film electrode exhibited increased photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) capability compared to a traditional TiO2 film electrode fabricated using the anodizing method for pentachlorophenol (PCP) degradation in aqueous solution. The bias potential, pH value, and electrolyte concentration were shown to be important factors influencing the degradation of PCP by the PEC method using the TiO2 nanotube film electrode as the working electrode.

mRY3dMc4.title: Effects of Fe2O3, organic matter and carbonate on photocatalytic degradation of lindane in the sediment from the Liao River, China.
mRY3dMc4.abstract: Fourteen sediment samples with different content of Fe2O3 were collected from the lower reaches of the Liao River in China. The photodegradation of lindane on the surfaces of these sediments was investigated to observe the effects of Fe2O3 and other photoinducable substances, such as TiO2 and organic substances, on photodegradation of lindane. A partial least-squares (PLS) analysis model was developed to find out the statistical relationship between the photodegradation and the contents of these photoinducable substances. It was concluded from the PLS analysis that inorganic carbon and organic carbon have negative effects, whereas Fe2O3 and TiO2 accelerate the photodegradation of lindane in the sediment samples when 365 nm UV light was used as light source. In all cases of the experiments, the photodegradation of lindane in the sediment samples were fitted for pseudo-first-order kinetics.

01Jn8Fqo.title: Electrochemically assisted photocatalytic degradation of phenol using silicon-doped TiO2 nanofilm electrode
01Jn8Fqo.abstract: Silicon-doped TiO2 nanofilm was fabricated by chemical vapor deposition which can control the Si-doping amount well and obtain the rapid deposition of film. The results of X-ray diffraction (XRD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses revealed that the introduced silicon might be incorporated into titania matrix. This incorporation helped to increase the thermal stability of titania, which was in favor of suppressing phase transformation from anatase to rutile and also inhibiting the growth of anatase crystallite at high calcination temperature. A significant blue-shift with enhanced absorption intensities was observed in the spectrum of UV absorption for Si-doped sample. The Si-doped sample with 5 mol % of silicon exhibited the best photoelectrochemical property, and its photocurrent density under UV light was 1.7 times that of TiO2 nanofilm. The photocatalytic (PC) and electro-assisted photocatalytic (EAPC) activities were investigated using phenol as a probe substance. Compared with TiO2 nanofilm, the Si-doped TiO2 showed better PC and EAPC capabilities in the degradation of phenol under UV-light irradiation. The kinetic constants of phenol degradation for the 5 mol%-Si-doped TiO2 in PC and EAPC processes under UV-light irradiation were 1.3 and 1.8 times as great as the values for the undoped TiO2 nanofilm. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

BCLKKpuP.title: Preparation, characterization and photoelectrocatalytic properties of nanocrystalline Fe2O3/TiO2, ZnO/TiO 2, and Fe2O3/ZnO/TiO2 composite film electrodes towards pentachlorophenol degradation
BCLKKpuP.abstract: Nanocrystalline TiO2 composite thin ZnO/TiO2, Fe 2O3/ZnO/TiO2 and Fe2O 3/TiO2 films were developed on titanium substrates by applying dip-coating technique formed by the sol-gel method. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) evaluated the surface characteristics of the films. Results on their structure and crystallinity were obtained by means of X-ray diffraction. The samples were also characterized by X-ray energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) and ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. The photocatalytic activity of these film; towards photodegradation of pentachlorophenol pollutant was examined and their efficiency was compared to those of the different TiO2 films. It has been shown that the film photocatalysts can efficiently decompose the pollutant. The photoelectrocatalytic degradation of PCP showed important variation that decreases in the order: ZnO/TiO2 > TiO2 > Fe 2O3/ZnO/TiO2 > Fe2O 3/TiO2. The results showed that Zn2+ doped could improve PEC activity of titania film electrode while Fe3+ doped can not improve that of titania film electrode.

VDOHiGsg.title: Photochlorination of bisphenol A by UV-Vis light irradiation in saline solution: Effects of iron, nitrate and citric acid
VDOHiGsg.abstract: Environmental context Chlorinated organic compounds are ubiquitous in the environment, and cause concern owing to their persistence and toxicity to organisms. In addition to anthropogenic sources, photochemical processes in saline waters could also yield chlorinated organic compounds. The present paper investigates the effects of iron, pH, nitrate and dissolved organic matter on the photochlorination of bisphenol A, a widely distributed endocrine disrupting chemical. Abstract Effects of several key influencing factors of environmental photochemistry, including iron, nitrate and dissolved organic matter (DOM), on the photochlorination of bisphenol A (BPA) were investigated. Iron promoted the formation of chlorinated BPA, but the rate decreased with increasing pH. This result was consistent with the results of laser flash photolysis, which showed that high pH decreased the formation of reactive chlorine species (chlorine radical, Cl2 •). Nitrate ion and citric acid, which was selected as an analogue of DOM, inhibited the chlorination of BPA separately. The results presented in this paper are helpful to get some idea of the degree of photochemical chlorination in aqueous environment. © CSIRO 2010.

TJ5IBw2L.title: Direct growth and photoelectrochemical properties of tungsten oxide nanobelt arrays.
TJ5IBw2L.abstract: A single-step route was developed for the direct growth of tungsten oxide nanobelt arrays by heating a tungsten sheet without additional catalysts or reactants. X-ray diffraction and Raman analysis indicated that the tungsten oxide nanobelts were monoclinic. The surface photovoltage signal and photocurrent density of the tungsten oxide nanobelt arrays clearly suggested a high photoconversion ability. Further investigation demonstrated that the photoelectrocatalytic activity of the nanobelt arrays was higher than that of a tungsten oxide film when using phenol as the probe molecule.

H3xOT0vN.title: Electrochemically enhanced adsorption of nonylphenol on carbon nanotubes: Kinetics and isotherms study.
H3xOT0vN.abstract: Removal of nonylphenol (NP) from aqueous solution has attracted widely attention due to its aquatic toxicity and potential to disrupt the endocrine system. In an effort to develop the effective and environment-friendly treatment method for NP, adsorption of 4-n-nonylphenol (4-NP) on multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) under electrochemical assistance was studied. The adsorption kinetics and isotherms were investigated at different polarization potentials and compared with those of open circuit (OC) and powder MWCNTs adsorption. The adsorption kinetics was simulated by the model including pseudo-first-order model, pseudo-second-order model and intraparticle diffusion model. The isotherm was simulated with Langmuir model and Freudlich model, respectively. Experimental results indicated that 4-NP is able to be efficiently removed at a potential of -0.6V. Comparing with that of powder MWCNTs adsorption, the initial adsorption rate υ0 at -0.6V increased 7.9-fold according to pseudo-second-order model and the maximum adsorption capacity qm improved 1.7-fold according to Langmuir model. The improved adsorption effect at negative potential was ascribed to enhanced π-π electron-donor-acceptor (EDA) interaction between 4-NP and MWCNTs under electrochemical assistance.
