KiR0dOB6.title: Electrochemical enhancement of adsorption capacity of activated carbon fibers and their surface physicochemical characterizations
KiR0dOB6.abstract: The adsorption of activated carbon fibers (ACFs) and their surface characteristics were investigated before and after electrochemical polarization. The adsorption kinetics of m -cresol showed the dependence on polarized potential, and the adsorption rate constant increased by 77.1%, from 6.38 × 10 −3 min −1 at open-circuit (OC) to 1.13 × 10 −2 min −1 at polarization of 600 mV. The adsorption isotherms at different potentials were in good agreement with Langmuir isotherm model, and the maximum adsorption capacity increased from 2.28 mmol g −1 at OC to 3.67 mmol g −1 at polarized potential of 600 mV. These indicated that electrochemical polarization could effectively improve the adsorption rate and capacity of ACFs. The surface characteristics of ACFs before and after electrochemical polarization were evaluated by N 2 adsorption–desorption isotherms, scanning electron microscope (SEM), zeta potential and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). The results showed that the BET specific surface area and pore size increased as the potential rose. However, the surface chemical properties of ACFs hardly changed under electrochemical polarization of less than 600 mV. This study was beneficial to understand the mechanism of electrochemically enhanced adsorption. Keywords Electrosorption Adsorption kinetics Adsorption isotherms Activated carbon fibers Surface properties 1 Introduction Electrochemistry is widely used in wastewater treatment because of its environmentally friendly advantage. Electrochemical treatment technologies include electro-oxidation [1–3] , electro-reduction [4–8] and electrosorption [9–15] . Electro-oxidation and reduction are Faraday processes containing charge transfer through the phase boundary. However, electrosorption, which is generally defined as potential polarization-induced adsorption on the surface of electrodes, is a non-Faraday process. After the polarization of the electrodes, the polar molecules or ions can be removed from the electrolyte solution by the imposed electric field and adsorbed onto the surface of the electrodes. Because of its low energy consumption and environmentally friendly advantage, electrosorption has attracted a wide interest in the adsorption processes for the treatment of wastewater and the purification of supplying water. The investigations suggest that electrosorption can effectively enhance the adsorption of metal ions. The electrosorption processes of ions are mature, and the corresponding industrial products have been developed. However, the electrosorption for organic substances is a new technology. Some researchers [16–21] are exploring the feasibility of electrosorption for organic substances. Plaisance et al. [16] found that the 34% enhancement of adsorption capacity for benzene by electrochemical polarization was achievable. Niu and Conway [21] reported that the polarization of C-electrodes could enhance the adsorption rate of pyridinium ion, 1,4-pyrazine and 1-quinoline in the wastewater. These investigations indicate that electrochemical polarization can enhance adsorption rate and efficiency of organic substances on C-electrodes. The capacity and rate of adsorption for porous materials depend on many factors, such as the nature of pore structure and the surface polarity [13] . It is well known that the surface area and pore size distribution of adsorbents play an important role during the adsorption processes. Besides the surface chemical properties and the interaction affinity between adsorbates and adsorbents, the surface area and the pore size distribution may be also affected by electrochemical polarization. Therefore, to understand the mechanism of the enhancement for the adsorption rate and capacity of activated carbon fibers (ACFs), the investigation of physical and chemical properties of adsorbents after electrochemical polarization is important. However, to the best of our knowledge, the investigation of characteristics for activated carbon after electrochemical polarization has not been found. The objective of this study is to investigate the effects of electrochemical polarization on the adsorption rate and capacity of ACFs. And the physiochemical properties of ACFs, such as BET surface area, pore size distribution, the surface morphologies, zeta potential and surface functional groups, were analyzed to better understand the mechanism of electrosorption. We selected m -cresol as target substance, which is one kind of noxious organic pollutants that is present in some industrial wastewaters and needs to be removed, to study its electrosorption rate and capacity on ACFs electrode. 2 Experimental 2.1 Pretreatment of ACFs The commercial polyacrylonitrile-based ACFs cloth (obtained from Anshan Activated Carbon Fiber Company, China) were first heated in boiling 5% NaOH for 1 h, which may avoid the desorption of trace organic compounds during the adsorption procedure. And then the ACFs seethed in 5% HCl for 1 h after a batch of deionization elution procedures was applied, which remove fines and inorganic ions that may dissolve during the adsorption measurements. At last, the ACFs treated by the above procedures was heated in boiling deionized water for 1 h, immersed overnight in the deionized water and washed to neutral. Then the washed ACFs was dried at 105 °C for 24 h [22] , and kept in a desiccator for use. 2.2 Characterization of ACFs The BET surface area and pore size distribution of ACFs before and after electrochemical polarization in the solution of 0.01 mol L −1 Na 2 SO 4 were carried out with an automated gas sorption system, using N 2 as the adsorbate at 77 K. Before the experiment, the ACFs were heated at 100 °C and outgassed to a vacuum of around 10 −5 Torr. The pore size was calculated using the BJH model in the range 2.0–100 nm. The surface morphologies of ACFs before and after electrochemical polarization were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-5600LV, Oxford, UK) with an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. The zero-potentials were measured by a Zetameter (Zetaplus V3.52, Japan). Six solutions of 50 mg L −1 of each ACFs ground after different polarization were prepared in bottles with CO 2 -free bi-distilled water with 1 mmol L −1 KCl. The pH value was adjusted between 2 and 12 by adding HCl and NaOH. The bottles were sealed, dispersed uniformly by ultrasonic treatment for 24 h and left to stabilize for 24 h before the measurements. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis was performed after grinding the carbon samples and mixing with KBr power to prepare sample-KBr pellets. The infrared spectra of ACFs were recorded at room temperature in the range between 400 and 4000 cm −1 using a Fourier transform spectrophotometer (IR Prestige-21, Shimadzu, Japan). Pellets thickness was kept constant by fixing the sample-in-KBr weight (180 ± 0.2 mg), using the same die diameter, being palletized under the same pressure and time. The ACFs contained in the pellets was 0.1 wt%. 2.3 Instrumentation and adsorption cell A conventional three-dimensional electrode system was adopted in the adsorption/elecrosorption investigation in both open-circuit (OC) and electrochemical polarization experiments. The experimental apparatus was in detail described in our previous work [23] . All experiments were performed with a CH Instruments Model 800A electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Corporation, China) for supplying bias potential, which was connected with a personal computer that was used to control the experimental parameters. The working electrode was a piece of ACFs (weight 30.0 ± 0.5 mg) connected by platinum wire, which was fixed by plexiglas with four big holes. Saturated calomel electrode (SCE) was selected as the reference electrode, and the distance between SCE and the working electrode was about 2.5 mm. The auxiliary electrode, a piece of platinum plate (25 mm × 25 mm) attached to another platinum wire, served as a current collector. And the distance between the working electrode and counter electrode was 45 mm. 2.4 Adsorption/electrosorption kinetics The adsorption/electrosorption kinetics experiments were carried out in the aqueous solution of 100 mL with 2 mmol L −1 m -cresol ( ) and 0.01 mol L −1 Na 2 SO 4 . The 1 mL solution was withdrawn at a given time intervals, diluted to 10 mL with deionized water and the concentration was measured by UV–vis spectrophotometer (JASCO V-550, Japan) at 271 nm. The adsorption rate constants of m -cresol were determined with the Lagergren [24] Eq. (1) , which is the first-order adsorption kinetics equation: (1) log ( q e − q ) = log ⁡ q e − k ads t 2.303 where k ads (min −1 ) is the adsorption rate constant, q e and q (mmol g −1 ) are the amounts of m -cresol adsorbed at equilibrium and time t (min), respectively. 2.5 Adsorption/electrosorption isotherms Isotherm experiments for m -cresol at different bias potentials, corresponding to adsorption/electrosorption kinetics, were carried out with fixed amount of ACFs (30.0 ± 0.5 mg). The amount of adsorbed m -cresol was calculated from the following equation: (2) q e = ( C 0 − C ) V m where C 0 and C are the concentration at the beginning and the equilibrium adsorption state, respectively. V is the volume of solution and m is the mass of ACFs. Isotherms in all experimental cases were fitted to two classical empirical models of Langmuir [25] and Freundlich [26] . (3) q e = Q L b L C e 1 + b L C e (4) q e = k F C e 1 / n where Q L is the maximum saturation adsorption capacity, b L the Langmuir constant, K F and n are the Freundlich constants. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The determination of electrosorption potential window for m-cresol In order to ensure that the m -cresol was not oxidized or reduced during the electrosorption process, the electrosorptive bias potential must be controlled. The cyclic voltammetries of solution without and with m -cresol were measured by electrochemical workstation at anodic polarization, respectively, and the results are shown in Fig. 1 . Steady increases and decreases observed in current with electric potential in both solutions indicate that no oxidation or reduction occurs in the range between 0 and 600 mV. Therefore, the electrosorption was carried out in this potential range to prevent m -cresol from being reduced or oxidized. 3.2 Adsorption/electrosorption kinetics To investigate the effect of electrochemical polarization on the adsorption rate which is necessary for the accurate design and model of adsorption processes, four experiments on adsorption/electrosorption kinetics were carried out with the initial m -cresol concentration of about 2 mmol L −1 , the ACFs weight of 30 mg, at room temperature, but at different bias potentials (OC, 200, 400 and 600 mV). The adsorption rate constants were determined using Lagergren adsorption kinetics equation and were found to be 6.38 × 10 −3 , 8.56 × 10 −3 , 1.14 × 10 −2 and 1.13 × 10 −2 min −1 at the polarization of OC, 200, 400 and 600 mV, respectively. The results (shown in Fig. 2 ) show that the adsorption rate constants and capacity are improved with increasing the bias potential of electrochemical polarization, indicating that electrochemical polarization can effectively enhance the adsorption rate and capacity of m -cresol on ACFs. The pH almost remained constant during the course of all experiments, suggesting that water splitting didn’t happen. According to the results of cyclic voltammetry, electrochemical degradation of m -cresol was unable to happen when bias potential supplied was below 600 mV. This implies that the enhancement of adsorption rate and capacity for m -cresol at bias potentials supplied is not due to direct electrochemical degradation or secondary reactions caused by active oxidizing free radicals, such as free hydroxyl radicals produced by electrochemical water splitting, but may mainly be due to the affinity between the surface of ACFs and m -cresol, enhanced by the polarization under electric field. 3.3 Adsorption/electrosorption isotherms The adsorption capacity of adsorbents is a very important parameter in the practical process design. Therefore, the adsorption isotherms at different bias potentials, OC, 200, 400 and 600 mV, corresponding to the polarization potentials for kinetics above-mentioned, were investigated at 25 °C for 22 h. Fig. 3 shows the experimental equilibrium data and corresponding ones fitted with the Langmuir and Freundlich isotherms. The results show that the adsorption capacity of m -cresol enhances with increasing polarization potential, indicating that the adsorption capacity of ACFs can be effectively improved by electrochemical polarization. The parameters for two isotherms were evaluated by least squares method based on an optimization algorithm and shown in Table 1 along with the average absolute percentage deviation, % D , which is determined as follows: (5) % D = 1 N ∑ i = 1 N q exp − q pred q exp × 100 % where N is the number of experimental data points, q pred (mmol g −1 ) the predicted amount of m -cresol adsorbed with the isotherm model and q exp (mmol g −1 ) is the experimental amount of m -cresol adsorbed. The experimental data is in good agreement with Langmuir with small percentage deviations and high correlation coefficient, suggesting that the adsorption of m -cresol at polarization is monolayer. And the b L increases as the potential supplied rose from OC to 600 mV, showing that the affinity force can be effectively enhanced by electrochemical polarization. The maximum adsorption capacity increases by 61.0%, from 2.28 mmol g −1 at OC to 3.67 mmol g −1 at 600 mV. 3.4 The characterization of ACFs before and after electrochemical polarization In order to understand the mechanism of electrosorption for m -cresol on ACFs, the surface characteristics of ACFs before and after electrochemical polarization were evaluated in this paper. The electrosorption was mainly monolayer that was mostly dependent on the BET surface area and the pore size distribution of adsorbent. Hence, the surface area and pore size distribution of ACFs before and after electrochemical polarization were investigated by N 2 adsorption. And the morphologies, zeta potential and surface functional groups were also investigated. 3.4.1 The BET surface area and pore size distribution The adsorption–desorption isotherms of N 2 on the ACFs were shown in Fig. 4 . Based on their shape, the adsorption–desorption isotherms of ACFs before and after electrochemical polarization are type I according to the BDDT classification [27] . All of the isotherms have two characteristic regions; one below the relative pressure ( P / P 0 < 0.2), where a rapid increase of adsorption uptake is observed with increasing P / P 0 . This indicates that the ACFs contain a large number of micropores. The appearance of hysteresis loops in the N 2 isotherms of all the ACFs indicates the existence of some mesoporosity [28] . The hysteresis loops, whose area were 45.0, 46.9, 49.7 and 53.2, corresponding to the initial, 200, 400 and 600 mV polarized ACFs, increase slightly with increasing polarized potential. This suggests that the mesoporosity is enhanced slightly, which is also indicated by the later average pores. The BET surface areas of ACFs are 1335, 1384, 1479 and 1561 m 2 g −1 , corresponding to the initial, 200, 400 and 600 mV polarized ACFs, indicating that the electrochemical polarization can improve the BET surface areas. Only the inelastic deformation of surface, which was caused by electrostatic repulsion and the expanded action of the adsorption enhanced under electrochemical polarization for water and adsorbates, can be measured by this measured method applied. It is well known that the specific surface area is an important factor affecting the monolayer adsorption capacity, which the higher BET surface area causes the higher adsorption capacity. The pore size distributions of ACFs calculated using BJH method were shown in Fig. 5 in the range 2–100 nm. It seems that the pores in the mesopore range, which are defined as pores of width between 2 and 50 nm, increase with the increasing potential in the experimental potential range. The mesopores contribution to the BET surface area of ACFs is usually smaller compared with micropores. However, they play an important role in the adsorption of organics [29] . Similar to the specific surface area measurement, only the inelastic deformation of pore size caused by electrochemical polarization can be measured by this measured method applied. The enhancement of adsorption capacity for m -cresol may mainly be due to the improvement of BET surface areas and average pore sizes besides the affinity between the surface of ACFs and m -cresol, enhanced by the polarization under electric field. 3.4.2 The surface morphologies The surface morphologies of ACFs before and after polarization were characterized by SEM and shown in Fig. 6 . In order to distinguish the morphologies of ACFs at different polarized potentials, the micrographs at the polarized potentials of 800 and 1000 mV were also shown. When the polarized potential is less than 600 mV, there is no evident difference in the surface of ACFs. When the polarized potential is over 800 mV, some pits are formed on the surface, indicating that the surface is electro-oxidized. Active oxidizing free radicals probably develop on the surface, which may oxidize the adsorbate during the electrosorption. Therefore, controlling the polarized potentials in the range between 0 and 600 mV is reasonable for the electrosorption of m -cresol. 3.4.3 The zeta potential The zeta potential can represent a characteristic and practical value for the prevailing functional groups containing oxygen on the surface of ACFs [30] . By means of zeta potential measurements, valuable information can be obtained on the change that occurs on the surface of ACFs after electrochemical polarization. Fig. 7 shows the zeta potential of the ACFs before and after electrochemical polarization in the presence of 1 mmol L −1 KCl solution as a function of the pH value. With increasing pH value of the solution, the excess of negative charges on the surface of the ACFs increases. The isoelectric points (IEP, it is the pH at which the zeta potential is zero) of as received ACFs and the ACFs after polarizing at 200, 400 and 600 mV, are almost identical for the pH value of 6.1. However, the IEP is 5.0 in case of the polarization of 800 mV. This indicates that the surface functional groups are not affected by the electrochemical polarization in the range between 0 and 600 mV. There are more acidic functional groups [30] on the surface of ACFs after polarization of 800 mV, which may be resulted in by electrochemical oxidation. This is consistent with the results of SEM micrographs. 3.4.4 FTIR It is generally accepted that electrochemical polarization can change the surface oxygen-containing functional groups of ACFs. In order to investigate the change of surface functional groups, FTIR is used to qualitatively identify the functional groups of ACFs. The surface functional groups of the original and electrochemically polarized ACFs were evaluated by FTIR and the spectra are shown in Fig. 8 . The results show that when the polarization potentials are less than 600 mV, there is no evident difference between original and polarized ACFs. However, new (3150, 1300–1000 cm −1 ) and higher relative intensities bands (1400 cm −1 ) occur in the FTIR spectra for the ACFs at polarized potential of 800 mV. In spite of the fact that the measurement procedure applied here makes quantitative comparison of the FTIR spectra impossible, the presence and relative intensities of the respective bands indicate that some changes have occurred in the surface chemical structure of ACFs. The new band at around 3150 cm −1 is present, which may be assigned to the stretching vibration of O H⋯O formed on the surface [31,32] . The band in the region of 1400 cm −1 , which was intensified after the polarization of 800 mV, can be ascribed to carboxyl-carbonate structures [33] . The broad absorption within the range 1300–1000 cm −1 can be assigned to various C O bonds, such as those in ethers, phenols and hydroxyl groups [34] . Therefore, the surface of ACFs is probably oxidized at the polarization of 800 mV, but not at 600 mV, which is consistent with the results of SEM and zeta potential. 4 Conclusions In a summary, the electrochemical polarization can effectively enhance the adsorption rate and capacity of ACFs for m -cresol. In all experimental cases, the adsorption kinetics is fitted to the first-order adsorption kinetics. The adsorption isotherms obtained for m -cresol at different potentials follow Langmuir isotherm model. And the maximum adsorption capacity increases by 61.0%, from 2.28 mmol g −1 at OC to 3.67 mmol g −1 at 600 mV. The ACFs before and after polarization were characterized by BET, SEM, zeta potential and FTIR. The BET results show that the surface area and average pore size increase with increasing the polarized potential. The results of the other characteristics suggest that the surface of ACFs is not oxidized when the potential applied is less than 600 mV. Therefore, the enhancement of surface area and pore size for ACFs probably plays an important role during the electrochemically enhanced adsorption process, being beneficial to understand the enhanced adsorption mechanism. JUb7QPqD.title: Enhanced oxidation of 4-chlorophenol using sulfate radicals generated from zero-valent iron and peroxydisulfate at ambient temperature
JUb7QPqD.abstract: An efficient advanced oxidation process, which is based on the zero-valent iron (ZVI)-mediated decomposition of peroxydisulfate (PDS) that results in the generation of very strong oxidizing species (sulfate radicals) in aqueous solution, is reported. Experiments were conducted in the dark using ZVI loading ranging from 0.05 to 0.40 g L −1 in the presence of PDS. The results showed that ZVI significantly improved the degradation efficiencies of 4-chlorophenol at ambient temperature. The optimum loading of ZVI was 0.20 g L −1 and 88% removal of 4-chlorophenol was observed in 1 h of reaction time. The addition of methanol and tert-butyl alcohol as hydroxyl radical and sulfate radical scavengers proved the presence of sulfate radicals in the ZVI-PDS reaction system. The degradation of 4-chlorophenol was accompanied by the formation of hydroquinone, 1,4-benzoquinone, and small molecule compounds such as oxalic acid and succinic acid. Therefore, hydroquinone pathway was regarded as the main step in the oxidation of 4-chlorophenol. Chloride ion release and formation of oxidation intermediates were evidence of 4-chlorophenol degradation involving sulfate radicals. Keywords Sulfate radical anion Peroxydisulfate Advanced oxidation process Zero-valent iron 4-Chlorophenol 1 Introduction In the past few decades, advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) such as O 3 , UV/H 2 O 2 , UV/O 3 , Fe 2+ /H 2 O 2 and UV/O 3 /H 2 O 2 had emerged as promising technologies for the degradation of recalcitrant organic pollutants [1–3] . All these processes which produced hydroxyl radicals as the primary oxidant assisted in environmental remediation. Hydroxyl radicals whose redox potential is 2.8 V vs. NHE are highly reactive species. More recently, the application of AOPs based on sulfate radicals in the field of wastewater treatment has been the subject of recent interest because sulfate radical anion, SO 4 − ( E 0 = 2.5–3.1 V vs. NHE) possesses higher oxidation potential than hydroxyl radical. Several studies had been carried out by the use of sulfate radicals for the degradation of a variety of chemical contaminants, such as azo-dyes, 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D), perfluorocarboxylic acids (PFCAs), and chlorinated contaminants [4–7] . These studies demonstrated that sulfate radicals are stronger oxidants than hydroxyl radicals, especially at elevated pH. Furthermore, the high reactivity of sulfate radicals could remain in the range of pH 3–8. Manoj et al. [8] also reported that cyanuric acid, an end product of the hydroxyl radical-induced degradation of atrazine, could be decomposed in aqueous medium using sulfate radical anion. The sulfate radicals could be produced from peroxydisulfate (PDS) or peroxymonosulfate via thermal, photochemical, radiolytic, or redox decomposition (Reactions (1)–(4) ). Although the reaction of sulfate radicals with organic substrates had received considerable attention, most studies had focused on the cobalt-mediated decomposition of peroxymonosulfate [9–11] . Experimental evidence suggested that Co(II) was the best catalyst for the decomposition of peroxomonosulfate and Ag(I) was the most efficient catalyst for the decomposition of peroxydisulfate [12,13] . However, there are significant drawbacks regarding the use of Co(II) and Ag(I) for environmental applications. The use of heavy metal, cobalt, may adversely affect human health and the quality of the environmental systems [14] . Therefore, for water treatment, it is interesting to develop environmentally benign methods with respect to environmental and economic considerations. (1) S 2 O 8 2 − + heat → 2 S O 4 − (2) S 2 O 8 2 − + h ν → 2 S O 4 − (3) S 2 O 8 2 − + e − → S O 4 − + S O 4 2 − (4) S 2 O 8 2 − + M n + → S O 4 − + S O 4 2 − + M ( n + 1 ) + Iron has been widely used in water treatment processes because it is relatively inexpensive, nontoxic and effective. Most studies on metal iron were mainly focused on the reductive transformation of halogenated organic compound under the anaerobic condition [15,16] . Previous investigations on the metal iron activation of peroxydisulfate or peroxymonosulfate were limited to Fe(II) or Fe(III) as the catalyst. Rastogi et al. [17] reported sulfate radicals generated from activation of peroxymonosulfate with Fe(II) for PCBs degradation in aqueous and sediment systems. Fe(II)-activated PDS system had been used in wastewater treatment, especially for in situ chemical oxidation using sulfate radicals [18,19] . However, there existed critical barriers to the practical application of Fe(II): the reaction was performed under acidic conditions, and the efficiency was too low. Evidence for the latter was that some of the sulfate radicals produced reacted with excess Fe(II) thereby lowering the concentration of sulfate radicals that were available to degrade contaminants in the system (Reactions (5) and (6) ). (5) S 2 O 8 2 − + F e 2 + → S O 4 − + S O 4 2 − + F e 3 + (6) S O 4 − + F e 2 + → S O 4 2 − + F e 3 + These factors are undesirable in the application, and a neutral or slightly acidic pH would be preferred. The use of zero-valent iron (ZVI) would not only overcome the disadvantages of Fe(II) but also has the advantages of avoiding the addition of other anions to the treated system. Bergendahl and Thies illustrated the effectiveness of using ZVI as the iron source in Fenton's oxidation for treating MTBE-contaminated water [20] . Bermner et al. also reported the degradation of phenol with hydroxyl radicals generated from zero-valent iron and hydrogen peroxide [21] . To the best of our knowledge, only few researchers have worked on the oxidation of contaminants by the combination of ZVI and PDS at room temperature. Liang and Lai [22] reported trichloroethylene degradation using zero-valent iron and peroxydisulfate, and their work focused on the peroxydisulfate decomposition and the surface morphology of zero-valent iron in the In-Situ Chemical Oxidation (ISCO) treatment. Moreover, Oh et al. [23] also investigated the oxidation of polyvinyl alcohol by peroxydisulfate activated with heat, Fe 2+ , and zero-valent iron. Complete oxidation of polyvinyl alcohol was obtained by ZVI-activated peroxydisulfate in 2 h. However, the reaction mechanism of sulfate radicals involved in the ZVI-PDS system at near neutral pH is still lacking, and the degradation pathway of contaminants using sulfate radicals needs further investigation. 4-Chlorophenol was chosen as the target compound because it is present in many chemical industry wastewaters from pulp and paper, dyestuff, pharmaceutical and petrochemical. The major objective of this study was to explore the mechanism and pathway of chlorophenol degradation by the combination of ZVI and PDS under near neutral pH conditions. In this study, ZVI loading, solution pH, the reaction mechanism, and the products of 4-chlorophenol degradation were also evaluated. From the environmentally-friendly point of view, the combination of ZVI and PDS for wastewater treatment provides a promising alternative as a new technology for contaminants elimination. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Sodium peroxydisulfate (Na 2 S 2 O 8 , 98% purity) was purchased from Kemiou Chemical Reagent Company (Tianjin, China). Iron powder (Fe 0 , 98% purity) was purchased from Shenyang Reagent Company (China). 4-Chlorophenol (99% purity), 1,4-benzoquinone (99% purity), and hydroquinone (98% purity) were obtained from Feixiang Chemical Company (Shanghai, China). All Chemicals were used as received. 2.2 Experimental procedure All experiments were performed at room temperature (20 ± 2 °C) in a 250 mL glass vessel using a total volume of 200 mL under constant stirring with a magnetic stir bar. The vessel was wrapped with the tinfoil in order to avoid any photochemical effects. Prior to the addition of PDS, the suspensions were stirred for 30 min to obtain uniform mixture. Samples of 1 mL taken at different reaction times were mixed with the same volume of methanol to quench the reaction, and the remaining 4-chlorophenol in the solution was analyzed. The initial concentration of 4-chlorophenol was 0.156 mM (20 mg L −1 ). All batch tests were carried out in duplicate at least to ensure the reproducibility of experimental results. The solutions were prepared in deionized water. Stock solutions of 4-chlorophenol were made in aqueous solution and stored in the dark at 4 °C. Sodium peroxydisulfate solutions were prepared no more than 7 days before use in the experiments. 2.3 Analytical methods The concentrations of 4-chlorophenol, hydroquinone, and 1,4-benzoquinone were measured by HPLC (Waters 2695) equipped with a SunFire™ C 18 column (150 mm × 4.6 mm, 5.0 μm) and photodiode array detector (Waters 2996). 4-Chlorophenol, hydroquinone, and 1,4-benzoquinone were detected with their corresponding peaks at 280 nm, 290 nm, and 245 nm, respectively. Mixtures of methanol (55%) and water (45%) were used as the mobile phase at a flow rate of 0.5 mL min −1 . For the identification of 4-chlorophenol and its degradation intermediates, liquid samples after silylation were analyzed with a gas chromatography (HP GC-6890) equipped with a mass selective detector (MSD-5973) and a capillary column HP-5 (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) (Agilent, USA). The carrier gas was He at a flow rate of 1.0 mL min −1 . A solvent delayed at 4 min, and full scan mode was used. The injector temperature was set to 240 °C, and the column temperature was ramped at 10 °C min −1 from 60 °C to 210 °C where it was held for 5 min. The mass spectrometry was operated at the electron impact mode. Concentrations of chloride and sulfate ions were analyzed with an IC (HIC-VP Super Shimadzu, Japan) coupled with a Shim-pack IC-A3 non-suppressor column (4.6 mm × 150 mm) and a CDD-10A vp conductivity detector. An eluent solution, containing 8 mM p -hydroxybenzoic acid, 1.6 mM Bis-Tris, and 25 mM boric acid, was pumped at a flow rate of 1.0 mL min −1 . The solution was measured by PB-20 pH meter (Sartorious, Germany). Ferrous ion was measured colorimetrically with 1,10-phenanthroline at a wavelength of 510 nm using a 721 spectrophotometer (Shanghai Xinmao Instrument Co., Ltd., China). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 ZVI-mediated activation of PDS for 4-chlorophenol degradation Experiments were conducted to determine the effect of ZVI amount on the removal efficiency of 4-chlorophenol by changing ZVI loading while keeping PDS constant of 0.78 mM and 4-chlorophenol concentration of 0.156 mM. The amounts of ZVI applied were 0.02, 0.10, 0.20, and 0.40 g L −1 and the particle size of ZVI was 10 μm. As shown in Fig. 1 , the degradation of 4-chlorophenol followed pseudo-first-order kinetics with respect to ZVI at all iron loadings used in 1 h of reaction time. The initial rate constants increased with the increase of ZVI loading from 0.02 to 0.20 g L −1 . However, the degradation rate of 4-chlorophenol decreased when the ZVI loading was further increased to 0.40 g L −1 . The degradation rates of 4-chlorophenol in the solution followed this order 0.20 g L −1 > 0.40 g L −1 > 0.10 g L −1 > 0.02 g L −1 with k values of 2.16, 1.20, 0.96, and 0.12 h −1 , respectively. The optimum amount of ZVI was observed in this study for achieving the highest degradation efficiencies of 4-chlorophenol. When the loading of ZVI was around 0.20 g L −1 , 88% removal of 4-chlorophenol was observed within 1 h. The interesting results would be discussed in the following section. This study showed that the addition of ZVI was highly effective in degrading 4-chlorophenol in aqueous solution. PDS alone did not induce any significant transformation of 4-chlorophenol in the absence of ZVI during 1 h of reaction time because sodium peroxydisulfate is relatively stable at or below ambient temperature (25 °C). In the presence of ZVI alone, no significant degradation of 4-chlorophenol was observed. Joo et al. [24] reported that in the presence of oxygen, benzoic acid could also be oxidized by hydroxyl radical and other oxidants generated during the corrosion process of ZVI. In this study, the oxidation of 4-chlorophenol due to ZVI corrosion could be neglected. 3.2 Trend of iron species change in the ZVI-PDS system To further confirm the role of ZVI in the ZVI-PDS system, we investigated the concentration of ferrous ion in aqueous solution at near neutral pH 6.0. Fig. 2 shows the trend of ferrous ion in the different loadings of ZVI in the ZVI-PDS system. The loading of ZVI was in the range of 0.02–0.40 g L −1 , and the concentrations of ferrous ion increased with increasing amount of ZVI. There are two hypothesized possibility for the generation of ferrous ion in the ZVI-PDS system: one is due to the direct electron transfer from ZVI to PDS in a Haber–Weiss like mechanism during Fenton-like reaction. The other is due to the corrosion of the metal iron under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions through the following reaction: (7) 2 F e 0 + O 2 + 2 H 2 O → 2 F e 2 + + 4 O H − (8) F e 0 + 2 H 2 O → F e 2 + + 2 O H − + H 2 Iron is a strong electron donor ( E 0 (Fe 2+ /Fe 0 ) = −0.447 V vs. NHE), and it is possible that it can induce reductive decomposition of PDS. Moreover, because PDS ( E 0 = 2.01 V vs. NHE) by itself is an oxidant, which tends to abstract electron to form sulfate radical, the presence of PDS promotes ZVI dissolution (Reaction (9) ), similar to aqueous oxygen. Although the reaction of ZVI and PDS was thermodynamically favorable, it was a slow process at near neutral pH 6.0. (9) S 2 O 8 2 − + F e 0 → 2 S O 4 2 − + F e 2 + (10) 2 F e 3 + + F e 0 → 3 F e 2 + Zero-valent iron has been previously studied as a precursor of Fe(II) in acid media in Fenton reactions. However, in this study, the experiment was performed in near neutral pH medium. The initial product of ZVI corrosion is Fe(II) in accordance with Reactions (7) and (8) . Moreover, the multivalent oxidation states of iron may enhance the electron transfer, causing high catalytic reactivity. The recycling of ferric iron at the iron surface through Reaction (10) is fast compared to the homogeneous Fenton process. When the amount of ZVI was 0.40 mg L −1 , the most amount of ferrous ion was formed, however, the degradation of 4-chlorophenol decreased. This can be explained that either scavenging of SO 4 − radicals in the presence of excess Fe(II) (Reaction (6) ) or the rapid conversion of all Fe(II) to Fe(III); thus limiting the ultimate oxidizing capability of the system. Although the mechanism of these reactions was not well elucidated, it appears that, generally, a two-electron transfer occurs directly at the iron surface, oxidizing ZVI to Fe(II) ions. These investigations showed that ZVI was the source of Fe(II), which activated PDS in the ZVI-PDS system. Once PDS was activated, sulfate radicals formed might initiate a series of radical chain reactions involving other radicals and oxidants, where organic compounds were usually degraded. Therefore, in the presence of PDS, ZVI is a good Fe(II) provider for the activation of PDS to sulfate radicals which degrade 4-chlorophenol. The degradation of 4-chlorophenol initiated by Fe(II)-PDS and Fe(III)-PDS was also examined. Compared with the homogeneous Fe(II)-PDS and Fe(III)-PDS, the heterogeneous system, ZVI-PDS was very efficient in the degradation of 4-chlorophenol at near neutral pH 6.0. The removal of 4-chlorophenol in the Fe(II)-PDS and Fe(III)-PDS system was only 31% and 17%, respectively in 4 h while 88% was obtained in the ZVI-PDS system in 1 h ( Fig. 3 ). As expected, when ZVI instead of Fe(II) was used, ZVI could gradually release Fe(II) into the aqueous solution and the removal efficiency of 4-chloropenol was enhanced in the process. In agreement with Liang, sequential addition of Fe(II) in small increments resulted in an increased TCE removal efficiency [25] . Therefore, ferrous ions released from ZVI participated in Fenton-like reactions. 3.3 Oxidative mechanism in the ZVI-PDS system It is thoroughly established in the literature that alcohols containing alpha hydrogen, such as methanol and ethanol, readily react with hydroxyl radicals and sulfate radicals. Therefore, methanol (MeOH) is widely used as the scavenger of hydroxyl and sulfate radicals. Moreover, alcohols with no alpha hydrogen such as tert-butyl alcohol (TBA) are effective quenching agents for hydroxyl radicals. We investigated the effects of MeOH and TBA on the degradation of 4-chlorophenol in order to evaluate the reaction mechanism and the species that played role in the ZVI-PDS system. About 88% of 4-chlorophenol was removed in the absence of alcohol additive. However, a 76% and 47% drop in the degradation efficiency was observed in the presence of MeOH and TBA, respectively ( Fig. 4 ). The results showed that the reaction was completely quenched by adding MeOH as OH radical and SO 4 − radical scavengers, while the addition of TBA only moderately influenced the degradation rate of 4-chlorophenol. According to the literature report, the rate constants for reactions of MeOH with hydroxyl radicals and sulfate radicals are 8.0–10 × 10 8 M −1 s −1 and 0.9–1.3 × 10 7 M −1 s −1 , respectively. Although TBA is effective quenching agent for hydroxyl radicals ( k = 3.8–7.6 × 10 8 M −1 s −1 ), it reacts much slower with sulfate radicals ( k = 4.0–9.1 × 10 5 M −1 s −1 ) than with hydroxyl radicals [26,27] . The phenomenon in the presence of MeOH provided evidence for the involvement of hydroxyl radical or sulfate radical mechanism in the ZVI-PDS system. Furthermore, because TBA is also a scavenger of hydroxyl radicals, the degradation of 4-chlorophenol in the presence of TBA should be primarily ascribed to the formation of sulfate radical anion generated from Reaction (5) . In Reaction (11) , hydroxyl radical would be formed, but this reaction is slow at near neutral pH ( k < 3 × 10 3 s −1 ) [26] . Therefore, we believe that sulfate radical anion as the dominant active species is responsible for the oxidation of 4-chlorophenol in the ZVI-PDS system. (11) S O 4 − + H 2 O → HS O 4 − + OH 3.4 Effect of pH The pH value of the solution is an important factor that affects the decomposition of target compounds in the ZVI system [28] . In order to observe the effect of pH on the degradation of 4-chlorophenol, experiments were carried out at pH 3.0 and 6.0. Initially, the pH of the solution was 6.0 without pH adjustment. In the other solution, the pH was previously adjusted to 3.0 using 0.1 M H 2 SO 4 . From the experimental data in Fig. 5 , we can observed that the removal of 4-chlorophneol was only 12% in the presence of ZVI alone at pH 3.0, and the removal of 4-chlorophenol with ZVI-PDS was 86% and 80% at pH 3.0 and 6.0, respectively. At pH 3.0, the addition of ZVI alone could degrade 4-chlorophenol, yet it demanded longer time than ZVI coupled with PDS. At pH 6.0, the degradation efficiency of 4-chlorophenol was 80%, similar to the removal at pH 3.0. This result suggests that lowering solution pH slightly improves the degradation rate of 4-chlorophenol as it causes fast disappearance of ZVI, and hence the enrichment of Fe(II). Huang et al. reported that the oxidation of MTBE in groundwater by peroxydisulfate was inhibited by carbonate ions reacted as sulfate radical scavengers [29] . Hence, in this study, the experiment was performed without buffers or ionic strength compensation to avoid potential complications due to reaction between these additives and sulfate radicals. Taking into account the practical application of the system, the optimum pH for the highest degradation efficiency of 4-chlorophenol by the ZVI-PDS system was at near neutral value 6.0. 3.5 Identification of the reaction products and mechanism As shown in Fig. 6 , the degradation of 4-chlorophenol was observed and also accompanied by the formation of Cl − and SO 4 2− ions as the main inorganic products in aqueous solution. The increase of chloride ion in the solution was detected for 2 h of reaction time, implying that the chlorine on the aromatic ring was first removed. This result was easily understood because the carbon–chloride bond energy was considerably weaker than the carbon–oxygen bond energy. The mass balance calculation of chloride concentrations demonstrated that chlorine on the aromatic ring of 4-chlorophenol was almost removed. Moreover, the formation of SO 4 2− resulted from decomposition of PDS showed that the reaction took place in the ZVI-PDS system. Identification of reaction products was critical in proposing the reaction pathways and mechanisms. In order to detect the intermediates of 4-chlorophenol in the ZVI-PDS system, we increased the initial concentration of 4-chlorophenol to be 40 mg L −1 . Significant formation of partial oxidation products was detected during the degradation of 4-chlorophenol. Fig. 7 shows that the formation of intermediates such as 1,4-benzoquinone and hydroquinone were observed during the oxidation of 4-chlorophenol in the ZVI-PDS system. The degradation of 4-chlorophenol was extremely fast in the first 1 h, and then was gradually slow in the following 2 h. In the degradation of 4-CP with initial pH of 6.0, a decrease in pH was observed. This could be explained by the formation of reaction products such as HCl and organic acids. On the other hand, in the ZVI/PDS system, peroxydisulfate decomposition results in bisulfate (HSO 4 − ) byproduct formation (p K a = 1.92), and therefore usually causes a pH decrease [22] . GC–MS analysis also revealed the formation of small organic acid such as succinic acid and oxalic acid. The results are in good agreement with those of previous reports that the majority of the products formed by sulfate radical attack on aromatics are hydroxylation products, which are also intermediates of hydroxyl radical attack [9] . Previous reports have shown that there are two degradation pathways in the photocatalytic degradation of 4-chlorophenol: substitution to form hydroquinone and hydroxylation to form 4-chlorocatechol [30,31] . Hirvonen et al. [32] also reported that products similar to the ones detected in this study were observed during oxidation of chlorinated phenols in aqueous solution. Because hydroquinone as well as its oxidation product 1,4-benzoquinone were detected throughout the reaction in the ZVI-PDS system, hydroquinone pathway was regarded as the first step in the oxidation of 4-chlorophenol. During the oxidation of 4-chlorophenol, the electron transfer and hydrogen abstraction were assumed to be the first step of the sulfate radical attack. A sulfate radical mediated attack on an aromatic leads to the formation of carbon-centered radicals via electron transfer from the organic compounds to the sulfate radical because SO 4 − as well as OH are electrophilic radicals [33] . The results on reaction intermediates indicated that hydroquinone and 1,4-benzoquinone were two primary intermediates from 4-chlorophenol degradation which were then further oxidized to succinic acid and oxalic acid after aromatic rings were broken, so the possible degradation pathway for 4-chlorophenol is depicted in Scheme 1 . 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed an advanced oxidation process that uses ZVI in conjunction with PDS, which is highly effective in generating sulfate radicals. This combination is an example of a heterogeneous oxidation reaction, and the reaction can take place at near neutral pH. ZVI-PDS system using zero-valent iron as the source of ferrous ions significantly improved the degradation rate of 4-chlorophenol. The formation of intermediates such as hydroquinone and 1,4-benzoquinone showed that hydroquinone pathway is the main step in the oxidation of 4-chlorophenol. This study indicated that the addition of ZVI in combination with PDS is a feasible alternative in the treatment of wastewater containing chlorophenols. Therefore, promising and eco-friendly oxidation system is likely an interesting contribution to the field of advanced oxidation technologies. PjrE91AB.title: Toxicological characterization of photoelectrocatalytic degradation of PCP solution with alga growth inhibition test
PjrE91AB.abstract: The regularities of the acute toxicity changes during the photoelectrocatalysis process of pentachlorophenol (PCP) and toxicity reduction under different conditions were investigated with 96 h-alga growth inhibition tests. The results indicate that photoelectrocatalysis can reduce the toxicity of PCP solution more effectively than direct photolysis and electro-oxidation. Toxicity of the treated solution decreased steadily during the photoelectrocatalysis process of PCP with a reduction of relative toxicity index to 11% of that of the starting solution after two hours of treatment. The optimum reaction conditions are as follows: the electrolyte (Na2SO4) concentration is 0.01 mol/L, and pH is around 7.

vdsfnYZ8.title: Structuring a TiO2-based photonic crystal photocatalyst with Schottky junction for efficient photocatalysis.
vdsfnYZ8.abstract: Facile and effective approaches were developed to fabricate the inverse TiO2/Pt opals Schottky structures on the Ti substrate. The as-prepared samples were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and diffuse reflectance UV-vis spectra (DRS), respectively. The results indicate that these samples were of ordered network, which was built by the Pt skeleton frame and the outer TiO2 layer. The TiO2 layer was identified as anatase with the preferential orientation of (101) plane. The experiments of short-circuit photocurrent (SCPC) and photocatalytic degradation of phenol were also conducted under the UV irradiation in order to evaluate the photoactivity of the samples. By tuning the red edge of photonic stop-band overlapping the absorption maximum of anatase (at 360 nm), both the UV absorption and the carrier separation of the samples were improved. The kinetic constant using the optimal inverse TiO2/Pt opals (0.992 h(-1)) was about 1.5 times as great as that of the disordered inverse TiO2/Pt opals (TiO2/Pt-mix) and was 3.3 times as great as that of pristine TiO2 nanocrystalline film (TiO2-nc) on Ti substrate.

CDovwLq7.title: Rapid and complete dechlorination of PCP in aqueous solution using Ni-Fe nanoparticles under assistance of ultrasound.
CDovwLq7.abstract: The Ni-Fe bimetallic particles have been laboratory prepared using sodium borohydride (NaBH4) as the reductant to reduce Ni2+ and Fe2+ in aqueous solution simultaneously, and characterized by TEM, XRD, BET and XPS. The particles were proved to be nanoscale amorphous alloy with an average diameter of about 30 nm and a BET surface area of 20.9 m2 g(-1). Experiments for dechlorination of pentachlorophenol (PCP) by the Ni-Fe bimetallic nanoscale particles in aqueous solutions were carried out under the enhancement of ultrasound. Major factors that influence the dechlorination efficiency, such as initial pH value, Ni content in the Ni-Fe particles, and output power of ultrasonic irradiation, were investigated. The results indicated that Ni-Fe nanoscale bimetallic particles were very effective for the dechlorination of PCP. Dechlorination efficiency was 46% in 30 min under the optimal condition without assistance of ultrasound, whereas it increased to 96% when ultrasonic irradiation was present. Initial pH value showed apparent effect on the dechlorination. As the pH varied from acidic condition to neutral condition, the dechlorination efficiency decreased dramatically. In addition, the dechlorination efficiency was improved with increased Ni/Fe ratio and ultrasonic output power. Less chlorinated phenols including tetrachlorophenol, trichlorophenol, dichlorophenol, monochlorophenol were formed during the initial reaction, and phenol was determined by GC-MS as sole product in the end of reaction.

zQ3QCUNt.title: Removal of ternary VOCs in air streams at high loads using a compost-based biofilter
zQ3QCUNt.abstract: Waste gases in the industry process are often characterized by the presence of multi-pollutants and concentration varieties of the compounds. In this study, the behavior of a biofilter system under high loads of ternary VOCs was studied. The biofilter was operated using a mixture of compost, lava and soil and applied to treat the air containing ethyl acetate, isopropanol and toluene. The biofilter treated up to 200 g m −3 bed h −1 of ethyl acetate and 120 g m −3 bed h −1 of isopropanol with percentage removals of nearly 100% and the empty bed retention time between 45 and 90 s. Toluene removal efficiencies were in the range of 40–100% with the inlet concentration about 0.5 g m −3 due to the inhibition of ethyl acetate and isopropanol. During the 3 months operation, filter media clogging/channeling, pH decrease and nitrogen loss from the media resulted in the deterioration of the biofilter performance. The results demonstrated that under the conditions of pH ranging from 6.4 to 7.4 and the nitrogen content of the media above 0.3 mg g −1 , the mixture of ethyl acetate, isopropanol and toluene could be treated effectively using a compost-based biofilter. Keywords Biofilters VOCs Biodegradation Ethyl acetate Isopropanol Toluene 1 Introduction A large quantity of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) is released from various industrial plants and processes. These VOCs will rapidly become atmospheric pollutants and are facing increasingly stringent environmental regulations. Toluene, ethyl acetate and isopropanol are among the key pollutants that are largely present in the emissions of color printing industries. Toluene is a hydrophobic compound and one of the 189 hazardous air pollutants (HAPs) listed in the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendment (CAAA90) proposed by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). Ethyl acetate and isopropanol, on the other hand, are hydrophilic and readily biodegradable compounds. The presence of the three compounds, as well as of other VOCs, in the color printing air emissions has been the subject of the recent environmental regulations. The relevant enterprises are thus required to apply an appropriate technology to reduce their emissions. The current control technologies for these VOCs, such as thermal and catalytic incineration, are usually cost intensive and are often companioned with the generation of nitrogen oxides. Biofiltration of off-gases containing VOCs is a relatively new application of bioprocess engineering in waste management and has proven to be an effective and economical technology [1–4] . Biofilters work by passing humidified polluted air streams through a bed of porous media that are capable of adsorbing gaseous compounds and supporting biological growth. Under optimum conditions, biodegradable contaminants are rapidly converted to carbon dioxide and water without the accumulation of intermediates or dead-end metabolites. The biofiltration of toluene and ethyl acetate were well studied by some previous researchers [5–9] . Deshusses et al. [10] studied the maximum elimination capacities (EC) of isopropanol and other VOCs by biofilters using a 48 h test. However, to our knowledge to date, little studies have looked at the biofiltration of the mixture of ethyl acetate, isopropanol and toluene despite that this situation exists in a large number of air emissions. Hence, it has importance of investigating the simultaneous biofiltration of mixtures of the three compounds. The primary goal of this work was to investigate the treatability of the mixture of ethyl acetate, isopropanol and toluene, emitted from printing industries with relatively high concentrations of ethyl acetate and isopropanol, using a compost-based biofilter. The experimental work was conducted for a period about 3 months during which the biofiltration of the mixture of ethyl acetate, isopropanol and toluene and their interaction on one another were focused on. Also, the effects of pH, nitrogen content and the packing media reconstruction on the biofilter performance were investigated in order to find the optimum range of media pH and nitrogen content that was required for the biofilter operation. The results of these aspects may provide useful information concerning the design criteria and operation of full-scale biofilters treating the streams from color printing works. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Biofilter set-up The biofilter ( Fig. 1 ) was made from a transparent Plexiglas tube having a 7.5 cm diameter. It was divided into three 30 cm high sections (referred to as the first, the second and the third sections from the top to the bottom), each section being filled to a height of 19 cm with equal amounts of the prepared filter-bed materials. In order to support the packing material and to ensure homogeneous radial distribution of the input gas, a stainless steel mesh was installed at the base of each section. The airflow, supplied by an air compressor was first to pass through a granular activated carbon canister to adsorb oil and VOCs, and then was divided into four fractions. The major portion of the air was humidified to ensure that the air humidity was above 95%. The other three portions of the air were allowed to bubble through liquid VOC (ethyl acetate/isopropanol/toluene) containers with temperature regulations. The previous separated airflows were then mixed in an air mixer and the resultant polluted humid input gas was carried to the top of the biofilter, i.e. the experiments were conducted in a down flow mode of operation. Ports were placed in the biofilter column between the bed sections and were used for gas and filter material sampling. Water was added from the top of the biofilter through a water nozzle. 2.2 Filter media The filter media consisted of a “mixed compost”, lava, and a kind of soil containing plenty of humic substances. The “mixed compost”, containing 30% pig manure compost, 30% compost which was produced by the other lab of our school and 40% dehydrated sludge from a wastewater treatment plant, had been stored in a barrel for about 3 months in the laboratory and was sieved to remove visible dirt and large floc particles before being used. The media was inoculated with activated sludge mixed liquor from the wastewater treatment facility of Dalian Chemical Industry Corporation, which had been cultivated with ethyl acetate and toluene for about 20 days. 2.3 Water content of the media Water content of the media is one of the most important factors that affect the performance of the biofilter [11–16] . According to Sun et al. [15,16] , the optimal initial water content of the packing media treating toluene and ethyl acetate ranged from 50 to 70% and from 40 to 60%, respectively. The results of Richard Auria's research [11] showed that ethanol elimination capacity was relatively high for water contents ranging from 49 to 70%. In order to maintain the water content of the filter media in this work, the air streams were humidified above 95% relative humidity (the apparatus used for testing the relative humidity was not sensitive when the relative humidity was higher than 95%) and water was added into the bed from the top of the biofilter according to the condition of the packing media. During this project, the water content of the packing media in the first, the second and the third sections ranged from 50 to 60%, 55 to 60% and 55 to 65%, respectively. 3 Analytical methods VOC concentrations were measured online and via chromatographic analysis using a Shimadzu 14A gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a FID detector. The inlet and outlet streams, as well as from between the biofilter sections, were sampled using an air sampling apparatus connected to a 6-position switching valve (Shimadzu) with a 1 ml loop. Aqueous extracts of the packing materials were obtained by shaking mechanically with distilled water at solid-double distilled water (DDI) of 1:5 (w/v) for 2 h. The suspensions were centrifuged at 10,000 rmp and filtered through 0.45 μm membrane filters. The following analyses were carried out on the water extracts: NH 4 + –N by the spectrophotometry method using Nessler reagent [17] , NO 3 − –N (including NO 2 − –N) by the method provided by Zhao et al. [18] . The gravimetric moisture content of the media was measured by the weight loss after the medium samples were dried at 105 °C for 2 h. To measure the pH values of the bed material, 5 g of packing media was blended with 25 ml distilled water and was determined using a digital pH monitor (Sartorious PB-S). Each time the media were sampled, the same amount (about 5 or10 g) of fresh media were added into the biofilter to compensate the media loss. 3.1 Operation and performance parameters Studies were performed on the level of the VOC inlet load (IL), the corresponding removal efficiency ( X) , elimination capacity (EC). The definitions for these parameters are set out below: (1) IL = Q C in V (2) X s = 1 − C out C in × 100 % (3) EC = Q ( C in − C out ) V where C is VOC concentration (g m −3 ), Q the volumetric gas flow rate (m 3 h −1 ) and V is the volume (m 3 ) of the packing bed considered; Subscripts “in” and “out” are referred to the inlet and outlet of the packing bed considered. EC is an actual removal capacity in the biofilter. It is usually less than load (IL) and sometimes equal to IL when 100% removal efficiency is achieved. Generally, the nearer the location is to the inlet, the higher the EC value is and the lower the removal efficiency is. If C i,s , C 1,s , C 2,s and C o,s are employed to stand for the concentrations of a substrate along the height of the biofilter (i.e. inlet concentrations, concentrations after the first and the second section, and outlet concentrations), the removal efficiencies after the gas passes the first section ( X 1,s ), the second section ( X 2,s ) and the third section ( X 3,s ) are calculated as follows: (4) X 1 , s = 1 − C 1 , s C i,s × 100 % (5) X 2 , s = 1 − C 2 , s C i,s × 100 % (6) X 3 , s = 1 − C 3 , s C i,s × 100 % Subscript “s” stands for a certain substance presents in the air stream (s = e, ethyl acetate, p, isopropanol, and t, toluene). All of these parameters were studied in accordance with the operating conditions, as summarized in Table 1 . The whole experimental period was split into five successive stages, i.e. A, B, C, D, and E, which were summarized in Table 2 . The biofilter was unpacked three times during the stage E. On day 51, the media were mixed mechanically and the water content was adjusted to 50–60%. On day 62, pH of the media was adjusted to about 7.3 using NaOH solution and the location of Sections 1 and 3 were exchanged before the reconstruction. On day 80, 30 ml of 20 g l −1 KNO 3 solution was added to each section of the biofilter. The average concentrations of ethyl acetate, isopropanol and toluene in the air emissions of a color printing works in East North China are about 1.0, 0.5 and 0.1 g m −3 , respectively. In the current experiment, the average influent concentrations of ethyl acetate and isopropanol during stages B–E were remained about 2.5 and 1.0 g m −3 , which were twice as that in the actual air emissions. In view of the fact that toluene is much more difficult to eliminate through biofiltration than ethyl acetate and isopropanol, toluene and ethyl acetate/isopropanol were introduced at a higher ratio than that of the actual air emissions. 4 Results and discussions 4.1 Overall biofilter performance The performance of the biofilter in removing the mixtures of ethyl acetate, isopropanol and toluene was studied for a period of 3 months. As shown in Fig. 2 , ethyl acetate and isopropanol could be completely removed by the biofilter, however, toluene removal efficiency varied between 40 and 100% despite the fact that toluene inlet concentrations were relatively low. In Deshusses’ study [2] , the maximum elimination capacity (EC) of ethyl acetate was 200 g m −3 bed h −1 (grams of pollutants per cubic bed media per hour), when high loads of ethyl acetate were biodegraded at the presence of toluene. When isopropanol and acetone were treated simultaneously, 90% removal efficiencies of isopropanol were obtained with influent loads about 133 g m −3 bed h −1 [19] . As shown in Fig. 3 , the biofilter in this study could provide a complete removal of ethyl acetate and isopropanol when the corresponding loads were below 200 and 120 g m −3 bed h −1 , respectively. Therefore, it is obvious that higher ECs of ethyl acetate and isopropanol could be obtained compared with the researches mentioned above. The interaction between the biodegradation of ethyl acetate and isopropnaol could only be investigated from the performance of the first two sections for the fact that the two pollutants were mostly removed by the first two sections and the third one took a minor role in removing the pollutants. Fig. 4 shows that maximum EC of ethyl acetate in the first section is about 350 g m −3 bed h −1 . In stage E, the EC values were not as homogeneous as that in the other stages due to the deterioration of the biofilter performance during this stage. Data depicted in Fig. 5 show that EC of isopropanol in the first section can achieve 150 g m −3 bed h −1 when the corresponding loads vary from 160 to 300 g m −3 bed h −1 , comparative to the maximum EC value (150 g m −3 bed h −1 ) reported by Deshusess [10] . The EC values of ethyl acetate in stage A (without isopropanol) were a little higher than that in other stages at the equivalent inlet loads, indicating that competition, including competition between the bacteria accumulation and between substances [20] , existed when isopropanol was simultaneously biodegraded with ethyl acetate. These kinds of competition are very popular in the biofilters treating the mixtures of some VOCs [21,22] . The maximum EC of toluene was only about 20 g m −3 bed h −1 and had a remarkable fluctuation ( Fig. 6 ). Also, it was found that the decrease of ethyl acetate and isopropanol removal in the upper two sections always occurred with the decrease of toluene removal in the air stream. Some examples of the VOC concentrations along the height of the biofilter are shown in Fig. 7 . It can be seen that little or no toluene removal occurred at the location where ethyl acetate and isopropanol concentrations were high, indicating that the presence of high concentrations of ethyl acetate and isopropanol inhibited the biodegradation of toluene. Similar inhibition has been found by other researchers [2–4,9] , however, the exact mechanisms related to this inhibition still remain unclear and the data reported by some researchers are somewhat conflicting [19–22] . Further research is required to determine the actual mechanisms of the inhibition in this situation. Table 3 provides the average removal efficiencies of ethyl acetate and isopropanol after the first and the second sections, together with the average removal efficiencies of toluene in the treated air. It could be noted that toluene removal efficiencies were apparently linked to the removal rates of ethyl acetate and isopropanol. The average toluene removal efficiency of toluene in the treated air was 97% during the period of stage B, when the average removal of ethyl acetate and isopropanol after the first and the second sections was 87 and 93%, respectively. During the stages C and D, the removal rates of ethyl acetate and isopropanol in the first two sections decreased due to the increase of the gas flow rate, and thus the average toluene removal efficiency dropped from 97 to 80% and then to 56%. After the air flow rate had resumed to 0.1 m 3 h −1 during the stage E, the removal efficiency of the mixtures increased in the first 4 days, however, significant decrease was observed from day 47 onwards. On day 50, the removal efficiency of ethyl acetate and isopropanol in the first section was only 35% (shown in Fig. 2 b), suggesting that significant deterioration of the first section of the biofilter had happened. Toluene removal efficiency on this day was 68%, much lower than that in the stage B though the removal efficiency of ethyl acetate and isopropanol after the second section (88%) was comparative to the average value in stage B (91%). This could be explained by the fact that the increase of ethyl acetate and isopropanol concentrations in the second section, resulting from the deterioration of the first section, increased the inhibition of toluene biodegradation in this section. It is obvious that the levels near to the inlet of a biofilter (the first section of this experiment), where the concentrations of pollutants are relatively high, will firstly deteriorate and the effective levels removing VOCs in the biofilter will go downwards, and accordingly, the performance of the global biofilter will deteriorate if this situation continues. Three factors were assumed to be involved in the deterioration of the biofilter performance, i.e. media compaction/channeling, acidification and nutrient limitation. In order to resume the performance of the biofilter and to evaluate the effects of these factors on the biofilter operation, several steps were taken up in stage E. 4.2 Media clogging/channeling Over a certain period of operation, clogging/channeling will occur in the packing media, partly owing to the media compaction along the air flow direction or the formation of an excessive amount of biomass [23–25] . Processes preventing the biofilter from clogging/channeling include physical/mechanical, chemical and biological approaches [23–25] . On day 51, the packing media in each section of the biofilter were removed and mixed mechanically before reassembling. Complete removal of the VOCs was achieved during days 51–53, indicating that clogging/channeling had occurred in the media after about 50 days of operation. The increase of VOC removal was mostly resulted from the improvement of the performance of the first two sections because toluene elimination capacities by the third sections had no obvious increase after the reconstruction ( Fig. 8 ). This phenomena suggested that clogging/channeling exerted a more significant effect on the performance of the first section compared to the third one, i.e. clogging/channeling was readily to affect the biofilter performance under a high VOC loads after a certain period of operation. From day 55 onwards, the removal efficiencies of VOCs decreased gradually ( Fig. 2 b), implying that there were still other mechanisms related to the deterioration of the biofilter performance besides the media clogging/channeling. 4.3 The variation of the media pH The measured pH of the media decreased gradually (listed in Table 4 ). Devinny and Hodge [26] studied the intermediates in an overloaded ethanol biofilter (load > 156 g m −3 bed h −1 ethanol) and found that the rapid ethanol consumption was associated with the production of acetaldehyde, acetic acid and ethyl acetate. Therefore, it was reasonable that acetic and acetaldehyde would be present in the media/air stream since ethyl acetate and ethanol existed in the air stream and the VOC loads were higher than 156 g m −3 bed h −1 in the whole biofilter. Ethanol could be detected in the air after the first section when ethyl acetate concentrations were higher than 0.6 g m −3 bed h −1 (data not shown). We tried to detect the presence of acetic acid but failed. The accumulation of the by-products in the media will decrease the pH as well as the elimination capacity for the pollutants. Another process resulting to the decrease of the media pH is associated with the nitrification of ammonium nitrogen (NH 4 + –N) to nitrate nitrogen (NO 3 − –N). Microorganisms can use both NH 4 + –N and NO 3 − –N as nitrogen sources when pollutants are assimilated. At the same time, the nitrifying of NH 4 + /NH 3 –N occurs at the aerobic conditions. If the media can neutralize the proton resulted from the biodegradation and the nitrification processes, the pH will be relatively constant, and otherwise, the acidification of the packing media will occur. It could be seen from Table 4 that media pH dropped more rapidly in the first section than that in the other two sections, suggesting that pH buffer (lava) could not neutralize the acid at high loads of ethyl acetate and isopropanol. On day 62, the media in each section were unpacked again and the pH of which was adjusted to about 7.0 ± 0.3, the first and the third sections were exchanged. The average removal efficiency of toluene in the treated air was below 80% after the pH adjusting, indicating that there were still some other factors affecting the biofilter performance. 4.4 The variation of nitrogen content One reason for using compost as a filter medium is that nutrients from the compost would presumably be formed by mineralization and diffuse into the biofilm to replace what is consumed by microorganisms. However, composts have a significant variation in C:N ratio and, even more importantly, some composts release all their nutrients within a few weeks, while others might have slower release rates but can provide nutrients for years. Nitrogen is one of the most readily depleted nutrient because it is a major constituent of the microorganism proteins and nucleic acids and makes up to 15% of the microbial cell dry weight. Therefore, nitrogen can be a limiting nutrient if adequate amounts are not available in the biofilter [27–31] . Generally, as contaminants are degraded, neither the form of the nitrogen nor the availability is constant with either time or location within a biofilter. Independent of the initial form of the nitrogen presents in the biofilter media, cell growth produces organic nitrogen. During cell death and decay, organic nitrogen is converted to ammonia, which, in turn, may be volatilized, nitrified, assimilated into new cells, or denitrified to nitrogen gas and/or ammonia in local anoxic or anaerobic zones. If the nitrogen recycling efficiency is less than 100% (i.e. denitrification, stripping, or leaching occurs), nitrogen can eventually be depleted from the media. As shown in Fig. 9 , NH 4 + –N content decreased along the length of the biofilter and with the operation time. However, NO 3 − –N content in the packing media did not drop distinctly until day 42, and the distribution of NO 3 − –N along the biofilter length was not as regular as that of NH 4 + –N. This trend may be resulted from the following aspects. Firstly, microorganisms prefer to use NH 4 + –N as nitrogen source when NH 4 + –N and NO 3 − –N co-exist in the media for NH 4 + is more similar to the organic form. Secondly, NH 4 + –N can be nitrified to NO 3 − –N. And also, NO 3 − –N is readily to leach out with the movement of water in the packing media [28] . During days 20–31 (stage B), the EC of the ethyl acetate and isopropanol in the first section ranged from 400 to 520 g m −3 bed h −1 with a retention time of 15–20 s. According to Demeestere et al. [31] , 0.1 mg g −1 NO 3 − –N seemed to be a threshold concentration of the microbial available NO 3 − –N, above which methanol elimination capacity up to 422 g m −3 bed h −1 were observed at the retention time of 25 s and under the load of 424 g m −3 bed h −1 . If the biofiltration of ethyl acetate and isopropanol followed this nitrogen threshold, the decrease of VOC ECs during days 46–51 ( Table 3 ) was not supposed to be the result of nitrogen limitation, because NO 3 − –N and NH 4 + –N content in the packing media ranged 0.2–0.4 mg g −1 . NH 4 + –N content in the media during days 62–80 was about 0.1 mg g −1 ( Fig. 9 a), this was more than 200 times lower than that in the initial media, implying that the release of NH 4 + N from the packing media was relatively slow during this period. NO 3 − –N content ranged from 0.1 to 0.2 mg g −1 during days 62–80 ( Fig. 9 b), which approximated to the threshold recommended by Demeestere et al. [31] . Therefore, nitrogen limitation was suspected to be one of the possible reasons that led to the deterioration of the biofilter performance. On day 80, 30 ml of 20 g l −1 KNO 3 solution was added to the media of each section, this would release about 0.7 mg g −1 NO 3 − –N in the media. The packing media were exposed to the air for about 8 h before being repacked to assure that the water content was in the range of 50 to 65%. Above 90% removal of toluene was achieved after the addition of KNO 3 solution ( Fig. 2 ; Table 3 ). The increase of pollutant removal proved that nitrogen limitation had occurred after about 80 days of operation and nitrogen addition was necessary during the operation of the biofilter. 4.5 The overall maintenances of the biofilter During the 95-day operation, ethyl acetate and isopropanol could be removed completely, however, toluene removal efficiencies varied between 40 and 100%. Toluene removal efficiency can be maintained above 90% only during some particular periods. These periods, along with the pH values and nitrogen content, are listed in Table 5 . The pH of the media in the first section ranged from 5.7 to 7.5. Considering the whole biofilter, the average pH values varied from 6.4 to 7.4. The soluble nitrogen content ranged from 0.3 to 3.1 mg g −1 during these periods, indicating that the nitrogen content in the packing media should be higher than 0.3 mg g −1 in order to remove the VOCs successfully. Several points, which are important to the performance of a compost-based biofilter subjects to high loads of VOCs, can be made about when the overall performance of the biofilter ( Fig. 2 ) and the distribution of the VOC concentrations inside the biofilter ( Fig. 7 ) are taken into consideration. First, the clogging/channeling of the filter media should be avoided. Second, the adjustment of media pH and the addition of nitrogen are necessary for maintaining the biofilter performance. And also, the three-layer biofilter was appropriate for removing the mixtures of ethyl acetate, isopropanol and toluene, in view of the distribution of the concentration of the three pollutants in the biofilter ( Fig. 7 ). This multiphase structure makes it easier to control the biofilter performance according to the conditions of the media in each layer. 5 Conclusions Biofiltration of ethyl acetate, isopropanol and toluene was performed through a laboratory scale three-layer biofilter under high loads of ethyl acetate and isopropanol. Cent percent removal of ethyl acetate and isopropanol was achieved with influent loads of ethyl acetate and isopropanol below 200 and 120 g m −3 bed h −1 , respectively. For toluene, the biofilter achieved a maximum elimination capacity of 20 g m −3 bed h −1 with the removal rate varying from 40 to 100% and at the empty bed retention time from 45 to 90 s. The relative lower removal rate was partly resulted from the inhibition by the presence of high concentrations of ethyl acetate and isopropanol. The pH of the media decreased obviously during the biofiltration process, this decrease was related to the formation of acid by-products and the nitrification of ammonium nitrogen to nitrite and/or nitrate nitrogen. The content of the soluble nitrogen (ammonium nitrogen and nitrate nitrogen) in the media decreased gradually and the nitrogen limitation would be the limiting nutrient ultimately if no nitrogen source were added. In order to maintain the performance of the biofilter, the optimum pH range of the media should be in the range of 6.4–7.4 and the soluble nitrogen content in the media must be above 0.3 mg g −1 . 2LBZqT05.title: Comparison of different extraction techniques for the determination of chlorinated pesticides in animal feed.
2LBZqT05.abstract: The performances of Soxhlet extraction, dive-in Soxhlet extraction, microwave-assisted extraction (MAE), accelerated solvent extraction (ASE), fluidized-bed extraction (FBE), and ultrasonic extraction (UE) for the analysis of organochlorine pesticides in animal feed have been investigated. ASE and MAE provided significantly better extraction efficiency than Soxhlet extraction. The concentrations were 126.7 and 114.8%, respectively, of the values obtained by classical Soxhlet extraction, whereas the results from FBE and dive-in Soxhlet were comparable with those from the standard Soxhlet procedure. The reproducibility of FBE was the best, with RSDs ranging from 0.3 to 3.9%. Under the investigated operation conditions UE was not efficient, with the recoveries of target compounds being about 50% less than Soxhlet. Additionally, the performances of Soxhlet, dive-in Soxhlet, MAE, ASE and FBE were validated by determination of the certified reference material BCR-115. The results from the extraction techniques were in good agreement with the certified values.
keywords: microwave-assisted extraction · fluidized-bed extraction · accelerated solvent extraction · animal feed · organochlorine pesticides

Gbparpym.title: Stimuli-responsive peroxidase mimicking at a smart graphene interface.
Gbparpym.abstract: A synergistic graphene-based catalyst was engineered by the in situ growth of "naked" Au-nanoparticles (NPs) on graphene sheets. The catalyst exhibits excellent switchable peroxidase-like activity in response to specific DNA.
