pDEnFvM6.title: Constructing graphene/InNbO4 composite with excellent adsorptivity and charge separation performance for enhanced visible-light-driven photocatalytic ability
pDEnFvM6.abstract: Graphene (Gr)/InNbO 4 composite with visible light response was fabricated by a facile one-step hydrothermal method. The prepared samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectra (DRS), respectively. The results indicated that InNbO 4 particles with monoclinic type mainly distributed on the Gr sheet uniformly. The samples had good visible light response. Photocatalytic degradation of Methylene Blue (MB) was conducted under the visible light irradiation (>400 nm) in order to evaluate the photoactivity of this photocatalyst. The kinetic constant of MB removal with Gr/InNbO 4 (0.0346 min −1 ) was 1.87 times that with InNbO 4 (0.0185 min −1 ). The enhanced photocatalytic performance of Gr/InNbO 4 was attributed to the improved adsorption performance and the separation efficiency of the carriers. With Gr/InNbO 4 as the photocatalyst the OH radicals be another type of oxidant in the photocatalytic process in addition to holes and electrons on Gr transporting from InNbO 4 participated the oxidation of MB adsorbed on Gr. Overall, the result of this work could provide a new way of the construction of a visible-light-driven photocatalyst with high performance. Keywords Photocatalysis Visible light InNbO 4 Graphene Adsorption 1 Introduction Heterogeneous photocatalysis is one of the potential approaches for removing organic pollutants mainly attributed to its strong oxidation power, moderate operation temperature, and relative “green” final products [1–4] . However, this process has limitation in practical applications because of the low quantum yield. Quick charge separation and surface reactions (participated by the electrons and the holes transporting to the surface of the photocatalyst) are the key steps of the photocatalysis. Many efforts have been devoted to improve the efficiency of the charge separation and surface reactions. The way of promoting the charge separation is to facilitate the transportation of holes or electrons by applying an external bias potential to the semiconductor electrode [5] or constructing the heterojunction [6,7] . The strategy of accelerating surface reactions is to enhance the capture quantities of electrons (adsorbed O 2 ) or holes (adsorbed H 2 O, pollutants, surface hydroxyl groups, etc.) by doping Si [8] or supporting photocatalysts with materials which have excellent adsorption ability [9–11] . Graphene (Gr) is a novel material that is expected to be a promising electron transporter due to its extremely high electron mobility, good stability, and excellent optic transparency [12,13] . In addition, Gr has great adsorption ability and is expected to be a good choice for adsorbent coated on photocatalyst. Thus, constructing Gr and photocatalyst composite may enhance the photocatalytic performance. Recently, the enhanced photocatalytic performance of Gr/TiO 2 composite was demonstrated [14,15] , which was largely attributed to the great adsorptivity, extended light absorption range, and efficient charge separation properties of the Gr/TiO 2 composite. However, TiO 2 semiconductor has a relatively large band gap of 3.2 eV, which cannot utilize the visible light. As for the composite of Gr and other photocatalyst, it is still unclear if the pollutant adsorbed on the Gr will be degraded on the local site of Gr or in the vicinity of the semiconductor surface. Several complex oxides (e.g. InTaO 4 , BiVO 4 , and Bi 2 WO 6 , etc.) with native small band gap have been under investigation aiming for utilization of visible light [16–19] . InNbO 4 is one of the kinds. It was calculated that the conduction band level ( E CB ) of InNbO 4 is −0.7 eV vs. normal hydrogen electrode (NHE), and its valence band ( E VB ) level is 1.8 eV vs. NHE [20] . The work function of a free-standing Gr sheet is 4.5 eV [21] , so the Fermi level E F of Gr, which can be calculated by the formula E F = E 0 (vacuum level) − W (work function), is −4.5 eV relative to vacuum level, or 0 eV relative to the NHE. The matching between the energy level of Gr and InNbO 4 makes Gr a good electron acceptor generated by InNbO 4 in Gr/InNbO 4 composite. In this paper, Gr/InNbO 4 composite was prepared by a facile one-step hydrothermal method to improve the photocatalytic activity of visible-light-driven photocatalyst. To our knowledge, few works have been published on the composite of Gr and visible-light-driven photocatalysts, including the preparation and their photocatalytic ability in pollution control. Organic pollutant of Methylene Blue (MB) with cationic group substituting the hydrogen atom of the aromatic ring, which may strengthen the inter force of Gr and aromatic ring, was selected to test the photocatalytic kinetics and mechanism of organics adsorbed on the Gr/InNbO 4 composite. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the Gr/InNbO 4 powder InNbO 4 powder was prepared by hydrothermal method. In detail, 0.391 g In(NO) 3 ·5H 2 O (purchased from Tianjin Jinke Research Institute of Fine Chemical Industry, China) was dissolved in 25 mL deionized water and then was mixed with the NbCl 5 solution, which was made by dissolving 0.270 g NbCl 5 (Aldrich, 99.9+%) in 25 mL deionized water. The pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 3.5 by 5 M NH 3 solution. The mixture was stirred for 0.5 h, and then was sealed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and heated at 270 °C for 24 h under autogenous pressure. After this procedure, the precipitates were filtered, washed with deionized water for three times, and then dried in an oven at 60 °C for 3 h. The graphite oxide (GO) was produced by the modified Hummer's method. Firstly, 1 g graphite and 23 mL of H 2 SO 4 were mixed vigorously at 0 °C. Three gram of KMnO 4 was then added slowly to the above solution in 40 min, followed by 60 min of sonication. After this step, the suspended solution was stirred continuously for 1 h, and 46 mL of water was added slowly to the suspension in 15 min. Subsequently, the suspension was diluted by 140 mL of water and 10 mL of H 2 O 2 (30%), and then being separated by centrifugation. The deposition was finally washed with hydrochloric acid (5%), filtered, washed with water, and then dried to obtain GO. Gr/InNbO 4 composite was fabricated by a facile one-step hydrothermal method. Briefly, 500 mg InNbO 4 and 15 mL of 1 mg/mL GO solution were added to deionized water and vigorously stirred for 1 h to get a homogeneous suspension. The suspension was then poured into a 50 mL Teflon-sealed autoclave and heated to 180 °C for 6 h. After that, the precipitate was filtered, washed with deionized water for three times, and then dried at 60 °C for 3 h. In addition, Gr was fabricated by the same method without InNbO 4 to serve as control. 2.2 Characterization The morphology of the samples was measured using a transmission electron microscopy (TEM; FEI-Tecnai G 2 F30 S-Twin). The crystal structure of the samples was identified by an X-ray diffractometer (Shimadzu LabX XRD-6000) with CuKα radiation, accelerating voltage of 40 kV, current of 30 mA and a scanning rate of 0.02°/s in the 2 θ range of 20–70 °C. UV–vis absorption spectra of the samples were recorded on a UV–vis spectrophotometer (UV 2450 Shimadzu) with a wavelength range of 250–800 nm. Surface photovoltage (SPV) was measured by SPV monitor. XPS of the samples was obtained by X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (AMICUS). 2.3 Photocatalytic degradation of MB The photocatalytic activities of the samples were evaluated by the degradation of MB in a single compartment photo reactor (4 cm × 5.5 cm × 7 cm). A 500 W Xe lamp (Shanghai Jiguang Light Company, China) served as the visible light source. The light was passed through a glass filter, which should shield any wavelength above 400 nm. The initial concentrations of MB solution were 5 mg/L. Prior to irradiation, the suspensions were magnetically stirred in dark for about 30 min. At certain time intervals, 3 mL aliquots were sampled and centrifuged to remove the particles. To probe the oxidizing species in the photocatalytic process, the formic acid (FA), a normally used hole scavenger, or tert -butyl alcohol (TBA), an efficient OH radicals quencher was added in the solution. The concentrations of the quenching chemicals were at 1 mM. The concentration of MB was determined by UV–vis spectrophotometer (UV-721, Xinmao) at 664 nm. To avoid photosensitization effect, the photocatalytic degradation of 2,4-dichlorophenol (2,4-DCP) was also carried out by a same procedure. The concentration of 2,4-DCP was determined by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Waters 2695, Separations module) with a Sunfire™ C18 (5 mm) reverse-phase column equipped with photodiode array detector (Waters 2996). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD Fig. 1 showed the typical XRD pattern of the prepared InNbO 4 and Gr/InNbO 4 powders. The crystal form of the InNbO 4 was identified to the monoclinic type by the diffraction pattern shown in Fig. 1 according to ICDD card No. 33-619 [22] . No characteristic peaks of the other impurities were observed. Compared to InNbO 4 , peaks for Gr were not observed in the diffraction patterns of the Gr/InNbO 4 , which might be due to low amount and relatively low diffraction intensity of Gr. We also observed that the crystal form of the InNbO 4 did not change in the process of Gr loading. 3.2 TEM As shown in Fig. 2 a , the shape of the InNbO 4 particles was regular hexagon and the size of them was about 100 nm in width and 200 nm in length. Gr were thin and big sheets with ripples ( Fig. 2 b), which might be able to provide enough surface area to host InNbO 4 particles. The InNbO 4 particles mainly distributed on the Gr sheet uniformly ( Fig. 2 c), providing enough contacting surface between Gr and InNbO 4 particles and also presumably provide good potential for carrier transport. Fig. 2 d showed the HRTEM images of Gr/InNbO 4 . It was found that the lattice structure of InNbO 4 was in distinctive order and the boundary between the InNbO 4 and Gr was clearly identified. 3.3 DRS It is well known that the optical absorption property, which can exhibit the spectrum range the catalyst can absorb and excite the catalyst to generate the hole and electron, is the key factor in determining the photocatalytic performance of the catalyst [23] . The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of InNbO 4 and Gr/InNbO 4 were illustrated in Fig. 3 . The InNbO 4 showed good absorption in the visible light region. Compared with that of InNbO 4 , there was no obvious red shift of the absorption edge of Gr/InNbO 4 . The result suggested that the abilities of absorbing the visible light between Gr/InNbO 4 and InNbO 4 were generally same. In an earlier publication, a decrease in band gap energy was observed for Gr/TiO 2 composite due to the formation of the Ti–O–C bond [14] . From the result of the DRS, we proposed that most of the carbon in the Gr/InNbO 4 were “free”. This speculation was certified by the XPS spectra of InNbO 4 and Gr/InNbO 4 . There were no obvious shift in binding energy of the peaks which was attributed to the In 3d , Nb 3d and O 1s between InNbO 4 and Gr/InNbO 4 . The result showed that the environment of the In 3d , Nb 3d and O 1s in InNbO 4 and Gr/InNbO 4 were nearly same. Thus, our results suggested that the carbon in the Gr/InNbO 4 had minimum effect on the InNbO 4 . 3.4 Photocatalytic degradation of MB and 2,4-DCP The photocatalytic activities of InNbO 4 and Gr/InNbO 4 were evaluated by photocatalytic degradation of MB under visible light illumination. Fig. 4 illustrated the C t / C 0 vs. reaction time for the degradation of MB and UV–vis spectra of MB with Gr/InNbO 4 as the photocatalyst. The degradation rate of MB by direct photolysis was 14.9% in 90 min, indicating that MB could be degraded under visible light illumination. The elimination efficiency of MB with Gr/InNbO 4 was 97.6% in 90 min, higher than that the efficiency with InNbO 4 (only 83.4%). It was found that the degradation of MB by photolysis and the photocatalytic elimination of MB with InNbO 4 and Gr/InNbO 4 followed the pseudo-first-order kinetics by the formula (1) . (1) ln C t C 0 = − k t In the above equation, k is kinetic constant. The k of MB removal in the photocatalytic process with InNbO 4 was 0.0185 min −1 , which was largely enhanced compared to that in the process of direct photolysis (0.00201 min −1 ), showing InNbO 4 had good visible-light-driven photocatalytic performance. The k of MB removal with Gr/InNbO 4 (0.0346 min −1 ) was 1.87 times that with InNbO 4 . The result implied that coating Gr on InNbO 4 could enhance the photocatalytic performance of InNbO 4 . In order to exclude photosensitized effect in the photocatalytic process, the photodegradation of 2,4-DCP over InNbO 4 and Gr/InNbO 4 composite under visible light irradiation was performed ( Fig. 5 ). The direct photolysis of 2,4-DCP served as control and 6.7% of 2,4-DCP was eliminated in the direct photolysis during 60 min illumination. Compared with that in the direct photolysis, the removal rate of 2,4-DCP in photocatalytic process was largely enhanced, which was 81.5% with InNbO 4 and 98.1% with Gr/InNbO 4 , indicating that InNbO 4 could be excited by visible light and degrade the pollutant with no absorption in visible light range. The k of 2,4-DCP removal with Gr/InNbO 4 (0.0538 min −1 ) was 2.10 times that with InNbO 4 (0.0256 min −1 ), showing that coating Gr on InNbO 4 could enhance the photocatalytic performance of InNbO 4 . This result was further certified the conclusion obtained in the photocatalytic process of MB. 3.5 Mechanism on enhancement of photocatalytic activity One possible reason for the enhanced photocatalytic performance of the Gr/InNbO 4 could be the synergistic role of Gr due to the charge transfer process between Gr and InNbO 4 . We have measured the SPV of the InNbO 4 and the Gr/InNbO 4 (shown in Fig. 6 ), which is one of many indexes evaluating the separation efficiency of the photogenerated carries [24,25] . It was found that the SPV of the Gr/InNbO 4 was obviously larger than that of InNbO 4 indicating that the introduction of Gr would improve the separation efficiency of the carriers generated in InNbO 4 . The result was attributed to the key fact that the E F is negative than the E CB of InNbO 4 . When Gr/InNbO 4 was illuminated by visible light, the InNbO 4 was excited and photogenerated electrons would transfer from the conduction band of InNbO 4 to Gr. Thus, Gr served as an acceptor of the generated electrons of InNbO 4 and effectively suppressed the charge recombination, leaving more charge carriers to participate the oxidation reaction and promote the degradation of MB. Adsorption performance of the targeted substance is very important for the surface reaction. To evaluate the adsorption ability of InNbO 4 and Gr/InNbO 4 , the residue rate of MB after 30 min stirring in the dark was determined. The residue rate of MB in the solution with InNbO 4 as the adsorbent was 89.5%, whereas that of Gr/InNbO 4 as the adsorbent was 80.7%. It was obviously that the adsorption ability of the InNbO 4 was enhanced by introduction of Gr, which is a prequisite for good photocatalytic activity [14,26] . A number of diagnostic experiments were conducted to understand the mechanism for MB degradation with InNbO 4 . The experimental results are shown in Fig. 7 . FA, a commonly used scavenger of holes was added in the solution to explore if holes participated in the degradation of the MB. In our experiments, the degradation of MB was almost terminated indicating the hole was the major role in oxidation of MB either as the oxidizing agent or the origination of OH radicals. In order to further identify the role of OH radicals in the MB degradation, TBA, an efficient OH radicals quencher was added into the solution. In the presence of TBA, the degradation of MB was not quenched obviously. From the above discussion we propose that the oxidation of MB with InNbO 4 as the photocatalyst was mainly attributed to holes. The similar experiments were done in the photocatalytic process with Gr/InNbO 4 , as illustrated in Fig. 8 . In the presence of FA and TBA, the eliminations of MB were decelerated, showing the holes and OH radicals all contributed to the oxidation of MB at the same time. Compared with InNbO 4 , another type of the oxidizing species ( OH radicals) in photocatalytic process with Gr/InNbO 4 was found. To judge if the electrons on Gr transporting from InNbO 4 is the origination of OH radicals which participated the oxidation of MB, molecular oxygen which generates OH by the capturing reaction of electrons was pumped into the solution. In the O 2 -staturated aqueous solution, the degradation of MB was enhanced significantly. The enhancement can be explained on the basis of the hypothesis that more O 2 molecules scavenged more electrons with consequently producing more OH radicals. This observation implied that electrons on Gr were responsible for the generation of the OH radicals, which then oxidized the MB. These OH radicals would give a preferential degradation of the MB adsorbed on the Gr which was in the vicinity to them. The collective observations implied that with Gr/InNbO 4 as the photocatalyst the OH radicals be another type of oxidant in the photocatalytic process in addition to holes and electrons on Gr transporting from InNbO 4 participated the oxidation of MB adsorbed on Gr by producing OH radicals. Based on the experimental results, a schematic mechanism for the MB degradation with Gr/InNbO 4 as the photocatalyst was illustrated in Scheme 1 . As irradiated, the InNbO 4 particles were excited and generated holes and electrons. Due to the matching between the energy level of Gr and InNbO 4 , the exited electrons quickly transported to Gr and then reacted with adsorbed O 2 on the Gr to produce OH radicals which oxidized the MB adsorbed on Gr at last. Meanwhile, holes left on InNbO 4 surfaces participated the degradation of MB either by direct oxidation or by OH radicals produced in the reaction of holes and its scavengers. 4 Conclusions Gr/InNbO 4 composite with visible light response was fabricated by a facile one-step hydrothermal method and its photocatalytic performance was tested by MB degradation under visible light irradiation. Compared to InNbO 4 , the enhancement of photocatalytic capability was achieved which was attributed to the enhanced adsorption performance and facilitated separation of photogenerated carriers. Furthermore, with Gr/InNbO 4 as the photocatalyst the OH radicals was another type of oxidant in addition to holes and electrons on Gr transporting from InNbO 4 participated the oxidation of MB adsorbed on Gr. We believe that the construction of composite of Gr and photocatalysts with the visible light response and the detailed mechanism discussion in this work will open up new perspectives on development of highly efficient photocatalysts for environmental remediation technology. ZapmAl33.title: Improvement of water-, sulfur dioxide-, and dust-resistance in selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH 3 using a wire-mesh honeycomb catalyst
ZapmAl33.abstract: A novel V 2O 5/WO 3/TiO 2/Al 2O 3/wire-mesh honeycomb (WMH) catalyst was prepared for selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with NH 3. The resistances to H 2O, SO 2, and dust were investigated for the WMH catalyst, which were compared with those for ceramic honeycomb (CH) catalysts. The results showed that the WMH catalyst kept above 95% NO x conversion in the broad temperature window (250-425 °C) and provided nearly 92% NO x conversion during H 2O and SO 2 durability test, which might be attributed to the unique three-dimensional structure. Furthermore, the WMH catalyst could provide nearly 90% NO x conversion during 40 h dust exposure experiment owing to the little dust deposition of 2.9 g/m 2, whereas the amount of dust deposited on the CH catalyst with the same cell density reached 6.7 g/m 2, which resulted in a decrease of the NO x conversion from 72% to 58%. © 2012 American Chemical Society.

6Z4nARHU.title: Applying an electric field in a built-in zero valent iron--anaerobic reactor for enhancement of sludge granulation.
6Z4nARHU.abstract: A zero valent iron (ZVI) bed with a pair of electrodes was installed in an upflow anaerobic sludge blanket (UASB) reactor to create an enhanced condition to increase the rate of anaerobic granulation. The effects of an electric field and ZVI on granulation were investigated in three UASB reactors operated in parallel: an electric field enhanced ZVI-UASB reactor (reactor R1), a ZVI-UASB reactor (reactor R2) and a common UASB reactor (reactor R3). When a voltage of 1.4 V was supplied to reactor R1, COD removal dramatically increased from 60.3% to 90.7% over the following four days, while the mean granule size rapidly grew from 151.4 μm to 695.1 μm over the following 38 days. Comparatively, COD removal was lower and the increase in granule size was slower in the other two reactors (in the order: R1 > R2 > R3). The electric field caused the ZVI to more effectively buffer acidity and maintain a relatively low oxidation-reduction potential in the reactor. In addition, the electric field resulted in a significant increase in ferrous ion leaching and extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) production. These changes benefited methanogenesis and granulation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images showed that different microorganisms were dominant in the external and internal layers of the reactor R1 granules. Additionally, fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis indicated that the relative abundance of methanogens in reactor R1 was significantly greater than in the other two reactors. Taken together, these results suggested that the use of ZVI combined with an electric field in an UASB reactor could effectively enhance the sludge granulation.

L0LCUzlc.title: A graphene-based platform for single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) genotyping.
L0LCUzlc.abstract: A facile, rapid, stable and sensitive approach for fluorescent detection of single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) is designed based on DNA ligase reaction and π-stacking between the graphene and the nucleotide bases. In the presence of perfectly matched DNA, DNA ligase can catalyze the linkage of fluorescein amidite-labeled single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) and a phosphorylated ssDNA, and thus the formation of a stable duplex in high yield. However, the catalytic reaction cannot effectively carry out with one-base mismatched DNA target. In this case, we add graphene to the system in order to produce different quenching signals due to its different adsorption affinity for ssDNA and double-stranded DNA. Taking advantage of the unique surface property of graphene and the high discriminability of DNA ligase, the proposed protocol exhibits good performance in SNP genotyping. The results indicate that it is possible to accurately determine SNP with frequency as low as 2.6% within 40 min. Furthermore, the presented flexible strategy facilitates the development of other biosensing applications in the future.

ipS7Cyon.title: Fabrication of photocatalytic membrane and evaluation its efficiency in removal of organic pollutants from water
ipS7Cyon.abstract: TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membranes with photocatalytic capability have been successfully prepared from colloidal titania sols by the sol–gel technique. Pore sizes of the resulting membrane were mainly controlled by the sol properties and the immersion time. A preliminary investigation of the sol–gel process, the membrane characterization and the stability of composite membrane were carried out using IR-spectra, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD). The results proved that TiO 2 immobilized on the support of Al 2 O 3 had anatase crystal structure in the calcination temperature range. Direct Black168 was used as the test pollutant for investigation of the multifunctions of photocatalysis and separation of TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane. Some operational parameters such as the pressure in the membrane cell, the initial pH and air flow were determined and the influence of various parameters was also discussed to obtain high reaction rates, high membrane rejection and operating stability. The removal of Direct Black168 with UV irradiation alone achieved 70% and the retention of the dye with membrane filtration alone reached 65% after 300 min in the continuous system. By combining the photocatalysis with membrane techniques, the removal efficiency of the dye was improved markedly and reached 82% after 300 min. Although the dye was not completely decomposed by photocatalysis, the degradation of the dye helped to enhance the composite membrane flux and prevent membrane fouling. It was possible to treat successfully Direct Black168 solutions (100 mg/L) by means of a continuous process obtaining good values of permeate fluxes (82 L/m 2 h). The TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane with photocatalytic function could be interesting for water purification. Keywords Composite membranes Titania sols Photocatalysis and separation Membrane rejection Permeate fluxes 1 Introduction Nowadays water pollution, caused by hazardous organic chemicals used in industry and agriculture, is a very serious problem. Food, pharmaceutical, pesticides, the textile dyeing and finishing industry produces large volumes of discharge effluent and is considered as one of the major industrial pollutants [1–3] . These effluents are usually treated by physicochemical, oxidative or, most commonly, active sludge biochemical processes [4,5] . The main drawback of the above processes is that they generally produce secondary pollution due to the introduction of chemicals and/or the possible accumulation of other bio-resistant species in the environment. As a new method, membrane separation processes have been studied in order to reuse waste water derived from many fields by means of nano and ultrafiltration of discharge effluent [6–8] or they have been coupled with other technologies as for instance the ozonation [9] . Membrane separation processes have already shown to be competitive with other separation processes for what concerns energy costs, material recovery, reduction of the environmental impact and achievement of integrated processes with selective removal of some components [10,11] . However, this technique only transfers pollutants from a phase to another and only displays a simple separation function. Photocatalytic reactions allow in many cases a complete degradation of organic pollutants in very small and innoxious species, without using chemicals, avoiding sludge production and its disposal. Over the past several years TiO 2 nanostructures have become a focus of considerable interest because they possess unique properties relevant to applications including chemical sensing [12] , photocatalysis [13] and photovoltaics [14] . TiO 2 photocatalysis proves to be a promising technology for purification and treatment of both contaminated air and water [15] . Chen et al. have reported a novel TiO 2 –based p–n junction nanotube photocalyst, which shows excellent photoactivity [16] . Some multicomponent or mixed oxides such as SrTiO 3 , BaTiO 3 , TiO 2 /ZrO 2 , K 2 La 2 TiO 3 , Ni 2 O 3 /TiO 2 − x B x , ZnO–ZnS and silica–titania have good photoactivity [17–23] . In particular, TiO 2 in the crystalline form of anatase has been widely used due to its low cost, its photostability and to the fact that it is not a noxious chemical. Although TiO 2 is known to be an excellent photocatalyst for removal of organic contaminants, the separation of TiO 2 particles creates another problem to be solved in practical applications of the process [24] . A major difficulty in the separation of TiO 2 particles from treated water arises because TiO 2 particles are too fine to be removed by gravity settling. Recently, some attempts have been made to effectively separate TiO 2 photocatalysts, for example, by coagulation, membrane separation, etc. [25,26] . The coagulation method also has another problem related to the production of chemical sludge that must be disposed. The membrane separation may increase the treatment cost in practical applications of the process. Another investigator tried to use a photocatalytic membrane reactor for degradation of toxic organic species such as 4-nitrophenol while immobilizing TiO 2 particles on different flat polymeric membranes by means of ultrafiltration [27] . Almost complete degradation of the organic pollutant was achieved after 5 h irradiation, but the membranes used were slightly damaged by UV irradiation depending on the membrane materials. This study explored the feasibility of combining the photocatalytic with membrane techniques for removal of organic pollutants. Therefore, we prepared successfully TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membranes with photocatalytic capability by sol–gel technique. It is foreseen that the TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane may have the multifunctions of separation and photocatalysis simultaneously and this kind of composite membrane may play an important role in photocatalytic reaction and separation process. In a word, the aim of this work is to understand this behaviour and to improve the performance of the composite membrane with photocatalytic function in order to take advantage of the benefits of both the photocatalytic and membrane technology for pollutants treatment. In this paper, Direct Black168 [28] was used as the test pollutant. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents Tetra- n -butyl titanate ([CH 3 (CH 2 ) 3 O] 4 Ti) was analytical reagent grade and obtained from Shanghai Reagent Company. Ethanol (C 2 H 5 OH), acetic acid (CH 3 COOH), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), hydrochloric acid (HCl), H 2 O 2 and other chemicals were AR grade and all obtained from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagents Development Centre. The high-purity water used in the experiment was double distilled and then purified with the Milli-Q system. The substrate of Direct Black168 dye was obtained from Shanghai Dyestuff Chemical Plant and used without further purification. Table 1 shows the properties of Direct Black168 and Fig. 1 displays its molecular structure. The alumina template membranes with 200 nm diameter pores were obtained commercially (Whatman Anopore filters, Fisher, Anodisc 47). 2.2 Preparation of TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membranes TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membranes were prepared using sol–gel method. Tetra- n -butyl titanate (5.0 mL) was added to 25 mL of ethanol, and the resulting solution was stirred in an ice bath. To a second 25 mL portion of ethanol were added 0.5 mL of water and 1.5 mL of acetic acid. The tetra- n -butyl titanate solution was removed from the ice bath and the ethanol/acetic acid/water solution was slowly added. Unless otherwise noted, the temperature was maintained at 20 °C. The resulting alkoxide was kept standing at 20 °C for hydrolysis reaction for 30 min, and then was irradiated with an ultrasonic cleaning bath for 10 min, resulting in the transparent TiO 2 sol. The alumina template membrane was immediately dipped into this solution for a certain immersion time. After the desired immersion time, the membrane was removed from the sol and dried in air for 1 h at room temperature. The composite membranes were then placed in a muffle furnace. The temperature was ramped to 400 °C (100 °C/h) and kept for 6 h, and then ramped back down (50 °C/h) to the room temperature. 2.3 Instruments and analysis methods The morphology of TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membranes was observed using scanning electron microscope (SEM, JSM-5600LV, Oxford, UK). The phases and structures of samples were identified by X-ray diffractometer (XRD, LabX-6000, Shimadzu, Japan) employing Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 30 mA over the 2 θ range of 20–100°. IR-spectra of dried TiO 2 sol samples were measured to investigate structural information and specific molecule-groups information (IR Prestige-21, Fourier Transform Spectrophotometer, Shimadzu, Japan). Concentration of Direct Black168 was measured by UV–vis spectrophotometer (JASCO V-550, Japan). The pH value was controlled by acidimeter (Basic pH Meter PB-20, Sartorius, Germany). 2.4 Membrane permeation, rejection and photocatalytic experiments The experiment of photocatalytic reaction was conducted in static system and continuous system, respectively. In static experiment, 100 mL of 50 mg/L Direct Black168 dye solution was used, and the temperature was maintained at room temperature. At given reaction interval, a 3 mL of sample was withdrawn, analyzed with a spectrophotometer at 610 nm and returned quickly. For dark reaction, the experiment was carried out in darkness. Continuous run experiment was conducted using a peristaltic pump and 1000 mL of 100 mg/L Direct Black168 was used. Composite membrane permeation and rejection experiments were performed using a vacuum pump. When the photocatalytic reaction was performed, a 300 W high-pressure mercury lamp with a characteristic wavelength of 365 nm was used as UV source, which was surrounded by quartz cooling thimble (25 mm diameter). The lamp was placed upper the reactor and the distance between its bulb and the surface of the photocatalytic membrane was 10 cm; the light intensity at this distance was 400 μW cm −2 . During the experiment, air was bubbled into the solution using an inorganic ceramic microfiltration membrane (inside diameter = 8 mm, length = 50 mm, average pore diameter = 0.2 μm) in continuous run experiment and porous capillary was used to dissolve air into the solution in static experiment. In fact, inorganic ceramic microfiltration membrane and porous capillary were able to maximize exchange surface in order to achieve optimal air dissolution into solution by means of microbubble formation. Direct Black168 solution was stirred by air bubbling in darkness for 30 min to establish adsorption–desorption equilibrium before the experiments started. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Investigation of the sol–gel process and membrane characterization 3.1.1 IR-spectroscopic investigations Fig. 2 shows the IR-spectra (KBr pellets method) of dried TiO 2 sol sintered at different temperatures in the range from 100 to 400 °C. The spectra of the samples treated up to 200 °C exhibit only slight differences. The high-frequency part of the spectra is dominated by the OH stretching (3100–3500 cm −1 ) and bending (1640 cm −1 ) of water [29,30] . The deformation modes of CH-stretching modes of alcohol groups from the alkoxide appeared in the range between 1300 and 1500 cm −1 [31] . The band at wave number near to 1100 cm −1 can be attributed to Ti(O–C)-streching vibration [32] . This clearly indicates that in spite of gelation and drying of the TiO 2 sol samples, some hydroxyl group (–OH) remained in coordination with the Ti-atom. Heat treatment of the gel at 300 °C leads to the decomposition of the alkoxide–additive complex and the formation of Ti–O group at 500–520 cm −1 [33] . The bands in the high-frequency range (3100–3500 cm −1 ) and between 1300 and 1700 cm −1 vanished nearly. It can be seen from the IR-spectra that organic groups are few at 400 °C, which was due to the combustion and carbonization of organic materials at this temperature. 3.1.2 XRD analysis Fig. 3 shows X-ray diffraction patterns of composite membrane samples at various calcination temperatures by sol–gel technique. In comparison with the XRD pattern of the standard anatase crystalline TiO 2 , the prepared composite membrane (at 400 °C) had already formed anatase crystal structure due to the presence of attributive peaks (2 θ = 25.4, 38.0, 47.8, 54.6°). As shown, anatase TiO 2 single phase was considerably obvious at 300 °C. As calcination temperature increased, the peak intensity as well as the number of peaks correspondingly increased which further indicated the transformation of the TiO 2 of amorphous to polycrystalline nature together with the presence of mixed phase. The corresponding crystal-type of TiO 2 was dominantly anatase-phase from 300 to 500 °C, which was very beneficial for photocatalytic degradation of organic contaminations [34] . In the following photocatalytic experiment, the TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membranes calcinated in air at 400 °C were used as photocatalytic membrane. The percentage of anatase and rutile of TiO 2 are 86% and 14% at 400 °C, respectively. The above results are in agreement with IR-spectra of dried TiO 2 sol sintered at different temperatures. 3.1.3 Electron microscopy Fig. 4 a shows surface micrograph of TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane with immersion time for 30 min. As shown, there are many fine and uniform pores in the composite membranes. The pore size is about 50–100 nm. In order to investigate TiO 2 tubules microstructures in the inside of composite membrane, surface TiO 2 layer of the composite membrane was removed by sand paper. The surface TiO 2 layer could endure strong basic solution and therefore inhibited the dissolution of Al 2 O 3 support. Then the membrane was glued to a piece of filter paper with the polished face up. The resulting composite was immersed into 6 mol/L NaOH solution for 5 min at 50 °C to dissolve the alumina, and then rinsed with 1 mol/L HCl and deionized water sequently. Fig. 4 b shows SEM image of TiO 2 tubules in the alumina membrane. It can be seen from Fig. 4 b that the TiO 2 tubules were about 50 μm long (the thickness of the alumina membrane) and had outside diameters of 200 nm (the diameter of the pores). Fig. 4 c shows cross section SEM image of TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane with immersion time for 30 min. As shown, the thickness of composite membrane is about 50 μm. Surface TiO 2 layer of composite membrane could not be observed obviously from the SEM image of cross section. The reason is that the surface TiO 2 layer may be very thin. TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane with photocatalytic capability after 180 min UV irradiation and membrane filtration was investigated using SEM ( Fig. 4 d). As shown, the TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane has coarse surface microstructure after being used six times. The reason is that Direct Black168 and its photodegradation products coated on the surface of composite membrane. Many fine and uniform pores in the composite membranes could still be observed after being used six times, but a sign of more and more large pores was shown, which may be owing to the dissolution of TiO 2 microstructure. 3.1.4 Membrane permeation and rejection All permeation and rejection measurements were evaluated using the membrane test unit. The test solution was pumped from a solution reservoir through the membrane cell and back to the reservoir. Permeate and retentate were recycled. The temperature of the system was kept at 298 K. The flow velocity through test cell was kept constant at 12.7 L/h. Fig. 5 shows deionized water permeation flux as a function of time at different pressure difference. As shown, in the studied pressure difference range, the initial deionized water permeation flux increases with increase of pressure difference. However, the flux attenuation becomes more and more rapid with increase of pressure difference. In particular, the deionized water permeation flux reduces almost 80% after 30 min at pressure difference of 0.10 MPa. It can be seen from Fig. 5 that the deionized water permeation flux is almost steady at different pressure difference after 30 min filtration. Moreover, the steady permeation flux increases also as pressure difference increases. The above results indicate that there is a critical pressure during the process of membrane filtration. The driving force in the membrane filtration increases faster than the resistance in the membrane filtration under critical pressure. The driving force and the resistance in the membrane filtration is produced by the increase of pressure difference. If the pressure difference is beyond critical pressure, the increase trend of permeation flux should become slow. Membrane rejection was determined using Direct Black168 solutions. Fig. 6 shows Direct Black168 steady retention of TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane at different pH. It can be seen from Fig. 6 that the optimal pH was about 3.5, and the Direct Black168 retention above pH 4.0 decreased with pH increasing. The reason is that surface of TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane is positively charged at acid solutions. Usually, anionic dye is more easily adsorbed by composite membrane than cationic dye. The surface state of composite membrane at different pH has great effect on adsorption of the dye on composite membrane. The surface state of composite membrane may change or damage under strong acidic conditions. Therefore, Direct Black168 retention decreased below pH 3.5. At the optimal pH, TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane obviously possessed better adsorption capacity, and therefore, the retention of Direct Black168 was relatively high. The results of Direct Black168 steady permeation flux at different pH are also in agreement with above conclusions. At pH 3.5, the permeation flux (after 60 min) of Direct Black168 is lower (82 L/m 2 h) than above or below pH 3.5, and but the retention is relatively high (60%) at this pH ( Fig. 7 ). 3.2 Photocatalytic activity 3.2.1 Static experiments Direct Black168 in water has a strong absorption peak at 610 nm and it is quite stable to the irradiation even with UV light at λ max = 365 nm ( Fig. 8 a ). When TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane ( Fig. 8 d) was used as photocatalytic membrane, the dye can be decomposed under UV irradiation, as indicated by the decrease in the absorbance at 610 nm ( Fig. 9 ). The removal of Direct Black168 achieved 63% after 180 min UV irradiation. H 2 O 2 was also added to reaction system, and the aim is to enhance photocatalytic efficiency. Fig. 8 c shows that Direct Black168 was degraded under UV irradiation when H 2 O 2 was added to reaction system. The relative efficiency of the processes shown in Fig. 8 can be summarized in the order of H 2 O 2 –TiO 2 membrane-UV > TiO 2 membrane-UV > H 2 O 2 -UV > H 2 O 2 -dark > UV. Fig. 10 shows that the relationship of −ln C / C o over time is linear ( C : the concentration of Direct Black168; C o : the original concentration). The linearity suggests the degradation of Direct Black168 follows pseudo-first-order dynamics in the studied concentration range. The reaction ratio constant was observed to obey the following order: 0.01184 min −1 (H 2 O 2 –TiO 2 membrane-UV) > 0.00707 min −1 (TiO 2 membrane-UV) > 0.00425 min −1 (H 2 O 2 -UV). The above results illuminated that TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membranes obviously show much better photoactivity. According to the principle of photocatalysis, the photoactivity mainly dependent on three factors [35] : (I) electron–hole generation capacity; (II) separation efficiency of photogenerated electrons; (III) transfer efficiency of electrons to surrounding supports or compounds adsorbed on photocatalyst matrix. The degradation mechanism appears to be the reaction of the dye substrate with some reactive species such as HO radicals formed in each process. It has been known that H 2 O 2 irradiated with the UV light at λ ≤ 370 nm produces the HO radicals and HO can oxidize dye molecules (Eq. (1) ). In addition, dye solution decolorization occurs through direct electron (e − ) transfer from the TiO 2 surface to the dye molecule [2,36] , as shown by Eq. (2) . Direct oxidation by reaction with holes (h + ) has also been reported by Houas et al. [37] , as shown by Eq. (3) : (1) Dye + OH → Dye − + H 2 O → degradation products (2) Dye + e − → Dye − → degradation products (3) Dye + h + → Dye + → degradation products Haarstrick et al. [38] reported that oxygen is the key molecule for hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 ) formation and accelerates photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants. Oxygen is well known for scavenging the photogenerated electrons (Eq. (4) ), impeding the hole–electron pair recombination process (Eq. (5) ) and freeing up the photogenerated holes for further reactions. Thus, sufficient oxygen is important for successful and efficient photocatalysis. In our experiment, air was bubbled simply into the solution. It had two important functions: supplied oxygen and stirred solution. Air flow, during the process of photocatalytic reaction, has been studied ( Fig. 11 ). As shown, the efficiency of photocatalytic reaction increases as air flow increases. However, the photocatalytic efficiency is very close at air flow of 0.5 and 0.8 L min −1 . This may be attributed to two aspects. One is that oxygen is sufficient for photocatalytic reaction at air flow of 0.5 L min −1 . Therefore, excessive air (0.8 L min −1 ) cannot improve photocatalytic efficiency. The other reason is that a great deal of air bubble produced at 0.8 L min −1 , which may affect photoabsorption on the surface of TiO 2 and less photo reaches the photocatalyst surface, resulting in slower photocatalytic reaction. (4) O 2 + e − → O 2 − (5) e − + h + → heat 3.2.2 Continuous experiments It was possible to treat successfully highly concentrated dye solutions using photocatalysis coupled with membrane technology. Therefore, removal of Direct Black168 was also tested in the continuous system. For this system, the following experimental conditions were used, i.e. 1000 mL of aqueous solution containing the dye Direct Black168 (100 mg/L) at 298 K and pressure difference of 0.05 MPa; air flow 1.0 L min −1 ; initial pH 3.5; in the experiment, the lamp was switched on after 30 min of mixing and running in darkness (to allow the saturation of the dispersion with oxygen and the achievement of steady-state conditions for the adsorption phenomena). Fig. 12 a and b shows the results of Direct Black168 in the retentate and in the permeate in the absence of UV light, respectively. The concentration of Direct Black168 in the retentate remained almost constant throughout the run, and only a small increase was observed after 300 min. The TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane had an average rejection of 60% at steady-state conditions, but the concentration of Direct Black168 in the permeate depended on the history of the run. By continuing the run without interruptions, a decrease of the concentration of Direct Black168 of the permeate was observed reaching a rejection equal to 65% after 300 min. Fig. 12 c and d shows the results of Direct Black168 in the retentate and in the permeate under UV irradiation, respectively. The concentration of Direct Black168 in the retentate decreased with irradiation time. It means that photodegradation reaction occurred under UV irradiation. The concentration of Direct Black168 in the permeate under UV irradiation is lower than that of dye in the permeate without UV irradiation. By combining the photocatalysis with membrane techniques, the removal efficiency of the dye was improved markedly and reached 82% after 300 min. Although the dye was not completely decomposed by photocatalysis, the degradation of the dye helped to enhance composite membrane flux and prevent membrane pollution. At the same time, we can also find that the continuous filtration at a given pressure difference can enhance Direct Black168 adsorption on the surface of composite membrane. The adsorption of pollutants on photocatalyst is an important factor of heterogenous phtocatalytic reaction. 4 Conclusions TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membranes were prepared using sol–gel technique. Pore sizes of the resulting membrane were mainly controlled by the sol properties and the immersion time. With the aid of IR-spectra, XRD, SEM, the morphology, microstructure, chemical features of the sol–gel process and the composite membranes were investigated. The results proved that the TiO 2 immobilized on the support of Al 2 O 3 had anatase crystal structure in the calcination temperature range. It is very beneficial for photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants. The TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membranes can be used for photocatalytic reactions and show better photocatalytic activity. The pH has a great effect on adsorption property of Direct Black168 on TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membrane. At optimal pH, the retention of Direct Black168 reached 65% after 300 min and moreover good values of permeate fluxes (82 L/m 2 h) was obtained. Good adsorption property great contributed its high photocatalytic activity. By coupling photocatalysis with membrane separation techniques, the removal efficiency of Direct Black168 was improved markedly and achieved 82% after 300 min in the continuous system. In a summary, according to our research, the TiO 2 /Al 2 O 3 composite membranes have the multifunctions of photocatalysis and separation simultaneously. The use of the two techniques in a single device can boost the efficiency without increasing in excess the complexity of the process. Moreover, coupling the photocatalysis and membrane techniques result a very powerful process with a great innovation in water purification. Such an innovation has important significance in exploring a new efficient method to solve water pollution problem. 0f1vQ5Yq.title: Visible light photoelectrocatalysis with salicylic acid-modified TiO2 nanotube array electrode for p-nitrophenol degradation.
0f1vQ5Yq.abstract: This research focused on immersion method synthesis of visible light active salicylic acid (SA)-modified TiO2 nanotube array electrode and its photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) activity. The SA-modified TiO2 nanotube array electrode was synthesized by immersing in SA solution with an anodized TiO2 nanotube array electrode. Scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), infrared spectroscopy (IR), UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectrum (DRS), and Surface photovoltage (SPV) were used to characterize this electrode. It was found that SA-modified TiO2 nanotube array electrode absorbed well into visible region and exhibited enhanced visible light PEC activity on the degradation of p-nitrophenol (PNP). The degradation efficiencies increased from 63 to 100% under UV light, and 79-100% under visible light (lambda>400 nm), compared with TiO2 nanotube array electrode. The enhanced PEC activity of SA-modified TiO2 nanotube array electrode was attributed to the amount of surface hydroxyl groups introduced by SA-modification and the extension of absorption wavelength range.

qtcesMF7.title: Nitrogen-doped diamond electrode shows high performance for electrochemical reduction of nitrobenzene.
qtcesMF7.abstract: Effective electrode materials are critical to electrochemical reduction, which is a promising method to pre-treat anti-oxidative and bio-refractory wastewater. Herein, nitrogen-doped diamond (NDD) electrodes that possess superior electrocatalytic properties for reduction were fabricated by microwave-plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition technology. Nitrobenzene (NB) was chosen as the probe compound to investigate the material's electro-reduction activity. The effects of potential, electrolyte concentration and pH on NB reduction and aniline (AN) formation efficiencies were studied. NDD exhibited high electrocatalytic activity and selectivity for reduction of NB to AN. The NB removal efficiency and AN formation efficiency were 96.5% and 88.4% under optimal conditions, respectively; these values were 1.13 and 3.38 times higher than those of graphite electrodes. Coulombic efficiencies for NB removal and AN formation were 27.7% and 26.1%, respectively; these values were 4.70 and 16.6 times higher than those of graphite electrodes under identical conditions. LC-MS analysis revealed that the dominant reduction pathway on the NDD electrode was NB to phenylhydroxylamine (PHA) to AN.

pohDCvjP.title: Photonic crystal coupled TiO2/polymer hybrid for efficient photocatalysis under visible light irradiation
pohDCvjP.abstract: Inverse TiO2 opal photonic crystal coupled TiO 2/poly(3-hexylthiophene) (bilayer TiO2/P3HT) was structured on FTO substrate for efficient photocatalysis under visible light irradiation (γ > 400 nm). We expected that the photocatalytic capability of this hybrid photocatalyst could be enhanced by the efficient visible light absorption owing to the photonic crystal structure and effective charge separation owing to the unique heterojunction built between TiO 2 and P3HT. The bilayer TiO2/P3HT photocatalyst was prepared first by depositing inverse TiO2 opal on FTO substrate via replicating polystyrene opal, followed by spin coating a layer of TiO 2 nanoparticles on the inverse TiO2 opal. The as prepared bilayer TiO2 was modified by P3HT via dipping method. Environmental scanning electron microscopy (ESEM) images demonstrated that the as prepared photocatalyst was composed of inverse TiO2 opal layer and TiO 2 nanoparticles layer. The UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra showed that the optical absorption for bilayer TiO2/P3HT was more intensive than for pristine TiO2 nanoparticle/P3HT (NP-TiO2/P3HT) in the range of 400-650 nm. The enhanced generation of photocurrent under visible light irradiation (γ > 400 nm) was observed using the bilayer TiO 2/P3HT. The results of photocatalytic experiments under visible light irradiation revealed that the pseudofirst-order kinetic constant of photocatalytic degradation of methylene blue using the bilayer TiO 2/P3HT was 2.08 times as great as that using NP-TiO2/P3HT, showing the advantage of the unique structure in the bilayer TiO 2/P3HT for efficient photocatalysis. © 2010 American Chemical Society.

sxO1jXvL.title: Adsorption of ionizable organic contaminants on multi-walled carbon nanotubes with different oxygen contents.
sxO1jXvL.abstract: Multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs), which are considered to be promising candidates for the adsorption of toxic organics, are released into aqueous environment with their increasing production and application. In this study, the adsorption behaviors of five structurally related ionizable organic contaminants namely perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS), perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA), perfluorooctanesulfonamide (PFOSA), 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-D) and 4-n-nonylphenol (4-NP) onto MWNTs with different oxygen contents (3.84-22.85%) were investigated. The adsorption kinetics was investigated and simulated with pseudo-second-order model. The adsorption isotherms were found to be fitted with Freundlich model and influenced by both the properties of organic chemicals and the oxygen contents of MWNTs. As adsorption capacity decreases dramatically with the increasing of oxygen contents, the MWNTs with the lowest oxygen contents possess the highest adsorption capacity among four MWNTs. For the MWNTs with the oxygen contents of 3.84%, the adsorption affinity related with hydrophobic interaction and π-electron polarizability decreased in the order of 4-NP>PFOSA>PFOS>2,4-D>PFOA. Furthermore, the adsorption characters of five contaminants were affected by solution pH and solute pK(a) considering electrostatic repulse force and hydrogen bonding, which showed the adsorption of MWNTs with lower oxygen content is much sensitive to solution chemistry.

SO1JlHqk.title: Regeneration of acid orange 7-exhausted granular activated carbons with microwave irradiation.
SO1JlHqk.abstract: An investigation was performed for the regeneration of three granular activated carbons (GACs) exhausted with acid orange 7 (AO7). The three GACs were made from different materials, i.e. coconut shells, almond nucleus and coal. The AO7 adsorption process was carried out in a continuous-flow adsorption column. After adsorption, the AO7-saturated GAC was dried at 120 degrees C, then regenerated in a quartz reactor by 2450 MHz microwave (MW) irradiation at 850 W for 5 min. The efficacy of this procedure was analyzed by determining the rates and amounts of AO7 adsorbed in successive adsorption-MW regeneration cycles. Effects of this regeneration on the structural properties, surface chemistry and the AO7 adsorption capacities of GAC samples were examined. It was found that after several adsorption-MW regeneration cycles, the adsorption rates and capacities of GACs could maintain relatively high levels, even higher than those of virgin GACs, as indicated by AO7 breakthrough curves and adsorption isotherms. The improvement of GAC adsorption properties resulted from the modification of pore size distribution and surface chemistry by MW irradiation.

mMT9ZHLJ.title: Enhanced catalytic ozonation by highly dispersed CeO 2 on carbon nanotubes for mineralization of organic pollutants.
mMT9ZHLJ.abstract: Heterogeneous catalytic ozonation, in which ozone is activated by various catalysts to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS), is an effective approach to degrade persistent organic pollutants in water. However, catalyst with high activity and good stability for catalytic ozonation still remains rare. In this work, a highly dispersed cerium oxide on oxidized carbon nanotubes (CeO-OCNT) were prepared and characterized by X-ray diffractometer (XRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and temperature-programmed reduction using hydrogen (TPR-H) experiments. The as-synthesized CeO-OCNT showed significantly enhanced catalytic performance for degrading organic pollutants during catalytic ozonation. The removal efficiency of optimized CeO-OCNT for phenol mineralization was 2-3 times of pure CeO and OCNT, and was also better than that of a composite with the same composition, which demonstrated a synergic effect between OCNT and CeO on CeO-OCNT for catalytic ozonation. The TOC removal efficiency exhibited no obvious reduction after five cycling experiments, indicating the synthesized CeO-OCNT possessed good reusability. Moreover, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and radicals quenching experiments revealed that hydroxyl radicals (OH) were the dominant ROS for organic pollutants degradation. The superior activity of CeO-OCNT for catalytic ozonation could be attributed to the well-dispersed CeO, the improved mass transfer, and the facilitated redox Ce/Ce cycling.

LF0ZXDJZ.title: Temperature-dependence of soil/air partition coefficient for polychlorinated biphenyls at subzero temperatures.
LF0ZXDJZ.abstract: Soil/air partition coefficients (K(SA)) were measured experimentally on a silty clay loam soil spiked with polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) over a wide range of environmentally relevant temperatures (-30 to +30 degrees C). Measured K(SA)-values ranged over 6.4 orders of magnitude, with log K(SA) from 4.3 for PCBs 10/4 at +30 degrees C to 10.7 for PCBs 77/110 at -30 degrees C. Higher than expected, K(SA)-values were observed at subzero temperatures (by up to one order of magnitude, at -30 degrees C). The plots of log K(SA) vs. reciprocal absolute temperature show a change in slope at 0 degrees C. A log-log linear regression of K(SA) vs. octanol/air partition coefficient (K(OA)) has a slope close to 1, indicating that K(OA) is a good descriptor of the interchemical variability in K(SA). Further study showed that K(OA)-based Karickhoff-type equations can perfectly fit experimental K(SA)-values.

OpvvGFLA.title: Temperature measurement of GAC and decomposition of PCP loaded on GAC and GAC-supported copper catalyst in microwave irradiation
OpvvGFLA.abstract: A sheltered type-K thermocouple was applied to record the temperature rising courses of granular activated carbon (GAC) in a microwave irradiation field under various conditions. The results showed that GAC could absorb microwave energy effectively and its temperature rose up to 1100 °C in a few minutes. This interaction of GAC and microwave was utilized to the preparation of GAC-supported copper catalyst. The catalyst was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), iodine number and adsorption isotherm. It was found that elemental copper distributed uniformly on the surface of GAC, and after loading copper, the adsorption capacity of GAC decreased due to occupation of adsorption sites by copper. Decomposition of a typical chlorinated organic chemical, pentachlorophenol (PCP), on virgin GAC and copper-loaded GAC was assisted by microwave irradiation. Firstly, PCP in water was adsorbed onto GAC, then PCP-loaded GAC irradiated by microwave in a quartz reactor. The results indicated that most of PCP adsorbed on virgin GAC was decomposed or bound irreversibly to GAC under 850 w microwave irradiation for 10 min, and less than 2% was transformed into intermediates. A more rapid decomposition rate of PCP was observed on copper-loaded GAC with larger amount of intermediates formed. Identification of intermediates was accomplished by gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC/MS) analysis. Keywords Microwave Activated carbon Catalyst Preparation Pentachlorophenol Decomposition 1 Introduction Microwaves are electromagnetic waves of which spectrum lies between infrared radiation and radio frequencies corresponding to wavelengths of 1 mm to 1 m (frequencies of 300 GHz to 300 MHz). Microwave radiation when applied to materials makes the dipolar molecules rotate and the ions migrate. The energy absorbed is dissipated as heat [1] . Microwave heating is therefore internal as compared to conventional heating which is external. Sources of microwave irradiation allow high temperatures and high rates of heating to be obtained [2] . A typical example of microwave heating material is its effect on carbon. When carbon is exposed to a microwave field, its temperature can rise to 1000 °C in a few minutes [2] . The reason can be explained by space charge polarization [3] . Some carbons have free electrons whose displacement is restricted by grain boundaries. When these carbons are subjected to an electromagnetic field, space charge polarization takes place. Entire macroscopic regions of the material become either positively or negatively synchronizing their orientation with the field. At low frequency, the polarization synchronizes its orientation with the field, but as the frequency of waves increases there is a phase lag between the polarization and the applied field. This leads to absorption of energy and Joule heating of the carbon particles. The temperature measurement in microwave field is regarded crucial for reactions. Some researchers [4] believe that traditional technique of thermocouples for temperature measurements cannot be applied inside microwave ovens due to the electromagnetic field and the metal probes interactions, while there are reports that a thermocouple introduced normal to the direction of the electromagnetic field does not influence the electromagnetic field distribution [5,6] . Menéndez et al. [7] compared an Inconel sheltered type-K thermocouple and an infrared pyrometer in measuring the temperature of carbon bed during microwave treatment and found that the obtained results for these two techniques were comparable. The selective-heating character of microwave gives us an advantage of energy saving in the heating processes. Microwave dielectric heating has been widely applied to catalyst preparation [8] , catalysis reaction [9] , and environmental remediation [10–13] . Among various novel methods used in the preparation of catalysts, microwave irradiation is developed as effective technique which can offer rapid drying, uniform distribution of active components, physically stronger pellet during preparation of catalysts and enhance conversion rate and selectivity with significant energy saving during the performance [14] . Lingaiah et al. [15] prepared a series of silica-supported Pd-Fe bimetallic catalysts by conventional as well as microwave heating methods. They found that the catalysts prepared with microwave irradiation had a different morphology and possessed a higher hydrodechlorination activity compared to their conventionally prepared analogues. Microwave-assisted treatment has been applied to the in situ soil remediation of sites contaminated with PCBs [11] , PAHs [12] , as well as the disposal of sludge containing heavy metals [13] . Another typical application of microwave is in the processing of packaging wastes [2] . Processes applying granular activated carbon (GAC) adsorption and microwave decomposition to the treatment of VOCs have shown considerable savings in energy consumption and process efficiency [16] . The purposes of this study are to monitor the temperature rising courses of GAC exposed to 2450 MHz microwave field under various conditions with a sheltered type-K thermocouple probe, and to explore the effects of microwave irradiation on the preparation of GAC-supported copper catalyst as well as on the decomposition of PCP loaded on virgin GAC and copper-loaded GAC. 2 Experimental Commercial coal-based GAC (Tangshan Corp., China) was first immersed in 10% diluted hydrochloric acid for 24 h, heated in boiling water for 30 min, washed with deioned water to remove fines and impurities and dried at 105 °C overnight before impregnating it with the active component. Catalyst with 10 wt.% Cu was prepared by impregnating the GAC with an aqueous solution of copper nitrate (Shenyang Agent Company, China). The suspension was mixed in a shaking bed at 250 rpm for 2 h and evaporated to near-dryness in a microwave oven at 640 w intermittent power for 2 min. The catalyst was subsequently calcined in a quartz reactor ( Fig. 1 ) with no air input by microwave irradiation at 100% power (850 w, 2.45 GHz) for 10 min. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the catalyst was recorded with a Shimadzu LabX XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. The surface morphology of the catalyst was determined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using Oxford JSM-5600 LV microscope assisted with energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) to analyze the approximate atomic composition on the examined surface. The samples were characterized at tension voltages of 15 and 20 eV, and the results were expressed as secondary electron images (SEI). Decomposition of PCP loaded on GAC and GAC-supported copper catalyst was carried out in a quartz reactor. Loaded GAC was obtained by mixing 100 ml of PCP solution (2000 mg l −1 , pH 10.0) with 10 g GAC in 250 ml flasks. The flasks were sealed and placed in thermostatic shaker (250 rpm, 20 °C) for 6 h to obtain equilibrium. Separation of GAC from the solution was completed by filtration. The schematic diagram of the experimental apparatus is shown in Fig. 1 . An 850 w modified domestic microwave oven at the frequency of 2450 MHz with continuous adjustable power settings was used. The quartz column reactor (34 mm i.d.) was installed into the microwave oven. At the bottom of the column, a perforated quartz plate was fixed to sustain GAC. GAC loaded with PCP was put into the column and treated by microwave heating under various conditions. The temperature rising courses of GAC were recorded with a sheltered type-K thermocouple probe, which was inserted to a point near the center of the carbon bed. The top of the column was connected to a condensing system. A vessel was used to collect distillate and the contaminant vapor generated passed through two bottles both containing 20 ml of 0.1 mol l −1 NaOH solution. The determination of PCP concentrations in the filtrate, distillate and alkaline absorption solution was performed by HPLC (PU-1580, UV-1575, Jasco Chromatography, Japan) using a Kromasil ODS (5 μm, 4.6 mm ×250 mm) reverse phase column, a methanol: water=0.8: 0.2 ml min −1 of the mobile phase and UV-absorbance detection (220 nm). Total organic carbon analyzer (TOC-V CPH , Shimadzu, Japan) was employed for distillate analysis. PCP amounts in GAC before and after microwave irradiation were also detected by HPLC. The pretreatment procedure was as follows: approximately 1 g of GAC was heated at 103 °C for 6 h to constant weight. After cooling to the room temperature, 0.100 g of GAC was accurately weighed. PCP in GAC was extracted by 20 ml mixture of acetone and dichloromethane (3:2 (v/v)), with 0.2 ml of 37% hydrochloric acid added (shaking at 250 rpm for 2 h, then ultrasonic extracting for 30 min). The extraction procedure was repeated for six times. Afterwards, the extract was evaporated in 60 °C water bath to incipient dryness. The resultant sample was dissolved in 10 ml acetonitrile and analyzed by HPLC. A gas chromatograph (GC) (HP6890) with a capillary column (HP-5MS, 30 m ×0.25 mm ×0.25 μm ) and a mass spectrometer (MS) (HP5973) were employed to the identification of intermediates and decomposition products. A solvent delay at 5 min, and full scan mode were used. The oven temperature was programmed from 60 to 260 °C (20 min) at a ramp rate of 15 °C min −1 . The injector temperature was 260 °C and the transfer line was maintained at 280 °C. The MSD was operated in the electron impact (EI) mode. The ion source temperature was 200 °C and the electron energy was 70 eV. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Temperature rising courses of GAC in microwave field According to the method presented by Menéndez et al. [7] , the temperature rising courses of GAC in microwave field under different microwave power, GAC dose and moisture content, were recorded by a sheltered type-K thermocouple. 3.1.1 Microwave power The temperature attained in the carbon bed depends on the nature of the carbon (dielectric properties) as well as on the microwave power applied to the sample. For a given carbon, the temperature can in principle, be modified by adjusting the input power [7] . One special point to be noted is that the power levels used here are continuous, not just timed mark/space ratio control. The investigated power series was 160, 320, 480, 640 and 850 w. GAC dose and water content involved were 10 g and 52.5%, respectively. The results were illustrated in Fig. 2 . It can be clearly seen that at larger microwave output power, the temperature of GAC bed rises more rapidly. When the microwave power was as high as 640 w, the temperature rose up to 1100 °C in 4 min. Since the highest temperature that the thermocouple can endure is 1200 °C, as soon as the displayed value is close to 1150 °C, the microwave oven must be turned off. 3.1.2 GAC dose As different GAC dose means different volume and height of GAC in the reactor, thus different GAC load to microwave irradiation, GAC dose greatly influences the receiving of microwave energy. The GAC doses investigated were 5, 10, 15, 20 and 25 g, with 850 w power and 52.5% moisture content. During the experiment, it was found that when the GAC dose was as small as 5 g, the thermocouple could not be utilized to indicate its temperature. Because when the amount of GAC is too small, the probe of thermocouple could not be immersed into GAC bed and it is exposed to microwave irradiation directly, which causes sparks on the tip of the probe. In that case, the displayed temperature value was not that of GAC bed, but that of the sparks. Although the temperature of 5 g GAC bed could not be determined by the thermocouple, it was observed that the GAC bed did not turn red in 10 min irradiation. In a subsequent experiment, the position of GAC bed was raised up to the center of reactor and the same phenomenon was observed. The temperature rising courses of GAC bed in other doses were exhibited in Fig. 3 . It seems that a larger GAC dose absorbs microwave energy more effectively and its temperature rises more rapidly at the beginning. However, the temperature rising rate of larger GAC dose decreased later. The reason was considered to be that more energy was needed to maintain high temperature for larger dose. And the 15 g dose was taken as the best in view of absorbing microwave energy and keeping high temperature. 3.1.3 Moisture content of GAC The moisture content of a sample has an effect on the final temperature it attains during microwave heating [17] . Changes in moisture content will alter the conductivity and permittivity of the sample, and hence the strength of the electric fields in the material and the power dissipated in it. Water has a high dielectric loss factor, so relatively small differences in moisture contents between samples will result in temperature differences between them. Generally, it is believed that microwave activation occurs much faster with dry carbon than with wet carbon. A series of four moisture contents of GAC were studied, i.e. 0, 16.8, 36.4 and 52.5%, with microwave power 850 w and GAC dose 10 g. The results were shown in Fig. 4 , which were consistent with that of Haque et al. [18] . They found that to heat 100 g of dry carbon from room temperature to 650 °C, about 0.2–0.25 kWh of microwave power input was required, whereas the same mass of wet carbon of approximately 50% moisture required about 0.4–0.6 kWh. 3.2 Decomposition of PCP on virgin GAC and copper-loaded GAC XRD measurement was carried out to analyze the status and crystal structure of copper on the support. Fig. 5 shows the XRD spectroscopy of virgin GAC and copper-loaded GAC. Sharp intensive peaks were observed in the characteristic positions of elemental copper structure at 2 θ =43.3 and 2 θ =50.4° for the prepared catalyst (dotted line). Unlike the prepared catalyst, the virgin GAC (solid line) shows very small crystalline structure related to copper at 2 θ =43.3°. This indicates that the crystalline structure of copper presented in the prepared catalyst is due to the decomposition of copper nitrate. The two SEM pictures ( Fig. 6 ) obtained on virgin GAC and copper-loaded GAC corroborate the results obtained on XRD. In the case of GAC-supported copper catalyst, agglomeration of elemental copper into large particles is clearly visible. From EDX analysis, it was found that the copper loading on this catalyst is about 12.6 wt.%. Iodine number provides an indication of the adsorption ability of GAC to small molecular compounds. This index was tested for the two GAC samples according to the National Standard Testing Methods of P. R. China (GB/T 12496.8-1999). The corresponding values for virgin GAC and copper-loaded GAC were 944.1 and 824.0 mg g −1 , respectively. It was because that for the latter sample, some adsorption sites were occupied by elemental copper after loading, as can be seen from the SEM images. The adsorption isotherms ( Fig. 7 ) of the two GAC samples to PCP were also measured according to the method provided by Mollah and Robinson [19] , the results were in consistency with that of iodine number. For the decomposition of PCP, the initial amounts of PCP loaded on 10 g virgin GAC and on GAC-supported copper catalyst were 199.52 and 198.78 mg, respectively. The operating parameters for PCP decomposition experiment were: microwave output power 850 w, irradiation time 10 min and moisture content 52.5%. The temperature rising courses ( Fig. 8 ) of the two GAC beds during PCP decomposition were also recorded by the sheltered type-K thermocouple. It seemed that water evaporated faster from the surface of copper-loaded GAC due to its less adsorption capacity to water molecules, so its temperature began to increase rapidly after 60 s microwave irradiation (about 40 s earlier than that of virgin GAC). But the overall temperature rising rate of copper-loaded GAC was smaller and its final temperature after 10 min microwave irradiation might be lower as observed from appearance status. The reason was that elemental copper loading on the GAC surface decreased its ability in absorbing microwave energy (some microwave irradiation was reflected by copper). From the HPLC analysis for the off-gas basic absorption solutions, it was found that anything could hardly be detected in these two cases. Organic solvent and acid extraction of the PCP-loaded GAC before irradiation led to a 55.4±1.5% recovery rate. The total amount of chemicals in distillate was indicated by the index of TOC. PCP residues left in virgin GAC and copper-loaded GAC and TOC in distillate after different microwave irradiation times were plotted in Figs. 9 and 10 . As can be seen from Fig. 9 , PCP was decomposed promptly on virgin GAC or on copper-loaded GAC. More than 95% was decomposed or bound irreversibly (carbonization) to GAC after 6 min microwave irradiation for PCP on virgin GAC and nearly 100% for PCP on copper-loaded GAC. One special issue to be mentioned is that PCP was decomposed more rapidly on the latter although its temperature might be lower. The faster decomposition rate was deemed due to the contribution from the catalysis effect of copper. Data in Fig. 10 indicated that the amount of TOC in distillate was minor compared to the initial amount of PCP loaded on GAC. And for the decomposition of PCP loaded on GAC-supported copper catalyst, much more TOC was formed in distillate. The reason was the same as that of temperature rising, i.e. faster water evaporating rate brought out more PCP and its derivatives into distillate. Identification of intermediates was performed by GC/MS analysis. For the distillate from virgin GAC, three main dechlorination intermediate products, tetrachlorophenol, trichlorophenol and dichlorophenol, were distinguished and some minor amount of dehydroxylation products, pentachlorobenzene and trichlorobenzene were also identified. For the distillate from GAC-supported copper catalyst, further dechlorination intermediates, chlorophenol and phenol were found besides those mentioned above. The detailed degradation mechanism of PCP loaded on GAC exposed to microwave irradiation will be discussed elsewhere [20] . 4 Conclusions The potential of microwave heating as an alternative to conventional conductive heating for the introduction of energy into reactions encourages researchers to use microwave power in various fields. In this study, the temperature rising courses of GAC exposed to microwave irradiation were recorded with a sheltered type-K thermocouple, and it was found that microwave power and moisture content of GAC sample were the two key parameters. Microwave oven with adjustable power settings and with full-power level of 850 w was employed to the preparation of GAC-supported copper catalyst. Compared to conventional catalyst preparation method, this novel method is energy and time saving, does not need inert gas protection and hydrogen reduction with highly dispersed GAC-supported elemental copper catalyst obtained. PCP adsorbed on virgin GAC or copper-loaded GAC was almost completely decomposed or tightly bound to GAC under microwave irradiation in a few minutes. All this has demonstrated the potential effectiveness of microwave irradiation in catalyst preparation and environmental remediation.
